About 45 million Americans now owe a stunning $1.6 trillion in student debt. That's roughly one in every four adults, nearly double the number who had higher education loans 15 years ago. Among millennials, the number is one in three, often cited as a reason why so many young adults can't afford to buy a home, get married, have a family or move out of their parents' basements.
But while there's definitely no denying that some people with student debt are having serious problems, the notion that the entire system is completely broken is just plain wrong, many experts say. Click the link in bio to read why student debut is bad, but it’s no reason not to borrow. | Cover Photo Illustration by Newsweek; Graduate by Burlingham/Getty | Spread by Eduardo Munoz Alvarez/Getty

In a new book, Virginia’s former governor Terry McAuliffe gives a behind-the-scenes look at the 2017 Unite The Right Charlottesville rally and how the violence could have been avoided. “I wanted to document exactly what happened, why it happened, what steps were taken to prevent violence, and what lessons we learned from the event,” McAuliffe said. President Donald Trump’s infamous statement about the rally and the “very fine people,” became a large part of the news itself. According to McAuliffe, President Donald Trump, “failed as the moral leader of our country that day. He came out of the closet and showed us who he truly is, a racist, plain and simple.” *

Following the Second World War, the U.S. occupied the Marshall Islands and used them for nuclear weapons testing between 1946 and 1958. The Marshall Islands tests made up only around 6 percent of the 1,054 carried out by the U.S. between 1946 and 1992, but the area bore the brunt of the energy yield. The researchers looked at soil samples, ocean sediment and external gamma radiation levels collected from the territory and found external gamma radiation levels that were significantly elevated. | Photo: AFP/Getty Images

Woodstock defined, in some ways, the entire baby boom generation. It was three days of peace, love and understanding and all that jazz. The truth is this: There were some 400,000 people who actually attended the event over three days in August 1969. But most of us experienced it through the documentary—and the soundtrack—that came out about six months after the event. The music was all-in-all pretty great, and a lot of acts from Joe Cocker to The Who to Sly and the Family Stone to Santana and, of course, Jimi Hendrix, had star turns. We sat through the recently re-released director’s documentary cut so you don’t have to. Hit the link in the bio to see what we came up with. | Photo: Clayton Call/Redferns/Getty *

Today, the U.S. drug supply is 90 percent generic, with the majority of these low-cost drugs manufactured overseas. In theory, the result was a win-win for foreign drug makers and American consumers alike. The former gained entry to the U.S. pharmaceutical market, and in return, the American public got access to affordable versions of lifesaving drugs. But a string of troubling revelations about the quality of foreign-made generic medicine has sharpened public concern. Generic drugs with toxic impurities, unapproved ingredients and dangerous particulates, or that are not bioequivalent to the brand, have reached American patients. For tens of thousands of patients, precision medicine is rewriting their cancer stories. The days when cancer patients receive one-size-fits-all regimens of chemotheraphy and radiation may soon be a thing of the past. By targeting each patient’s unique tumor, precision medicine is crushing once-untreatable cancers. The idea of this personalized medicine is that doctors will use genetic tests, of both the patient and the tumor, to determine the exact drugs or treatments that have the best chance of working. But only a fraction of patients currently benefit from this. Precision medicine is helping, at best, only a few percent of the nearly 2 million people who are diagnosed with cancer in the U.S. each year, and the fraction is much smaller among the 17 million cancer patients worldwide. To increase the number of patients eligible for treatment, doctors are turning to artificial intelligence for help. But can medicine close the gap? Hit the link in the bio to read more on precision medicine, artificial intelligence and how it is being used to help fight cancers. | Credit: janulla/Getty

Filipino devotees gathered for the Taong Putik Festival, translated to the “Mud People” Festival, on June 24th. Every year the residents of the Bibiclat village celebrate the Feast of Saint John by covering themselves in dried banana leaves, vines, twigs, and mud. This festival celebrates how rain stopped the execution of 14 villagers during the Pacific War in 1944. The residents considered this a miracle from Saint John and every year since then, they roll and cover themselves in mud to show their gratitude. | Photo: Ezra Acayan/Getty Images

You won’t be able to tackle Old Dhaka single-handedly, even with a guidebook. With its winding unnamed streets and back alleys, Old Dhaka is wedged between the commercial center of Bangladesh’s densely populated capital and the Buriganga River. It became the most important commercial center in East Bengal in the 17th century, producing and exporting muslin, a high-quality woven cotton. The Ahsan Manzil, a national museum, was the official residential palace and seat of the Nawab of Dhaka. Scientists have warned that Greenland will be ice-free in the next thousand years unless greenhouse gas emissions are substantially reduced. Using three different climate change scenarios, a team of researchers ran hundreds of simulations to see how the ice would respond in the future. Their findings showed that if we continue along our current trajectory of warming, 100 percent of Greenland's present-day ice mass will be gone. This could raise sea levels by over 23 feet. "We project that Greenland will very likely become ice-free within a millennium without substantial reductions in greenhouse gas emissions,” the scientists said. | Photo: @fursty

50 years ago, the men of the Apollo program traveled around 238,000 miles from home, the farthest anyone has ever traveled before or since. The astronauts relied on a primitive computer and a control room filled with people with lots of brain power, pencil, and paper. Today, orbital trajectories are calculated in seconds by supercomputers operating hundreds of millions of times faster than NASA’s 1969 model. Next week, on July 20th, marks the 50th anniversary of when we successfully landed on the moon and when Neil Armstrong took mankind’s first steps on it. The 50th anniversary of the first human moon-landing is a good time to take stock of what has changed on Earth and in America since July 1969. In honor of this historic accomplishment, we caught up with a few lunar astronauts. The trip to the moon changed these astronauts in ways they couldn’t predict. Hit the link in the bio to read their reflection of JFK’s challenge in 1962 to land a man on the moon and the future of space travel. | Cover: Charles Conrad Jr. /@NASA - Portraits by @instalane; Archival photos courtesy of @NASA

When people make friends, we often choose companions who share similar traits to us or enjoy participating in the same activities that we enjoy. Intriguingly, it turns out that dolphins may not be so different. 🐬 According to a study, dolphins form strong social ties with those who have similar interests. This behavior, known as "sponging," helps the dolphins find food in deeper waters and is socially-learned, being passed down from mother to calf. "These strong bonds between males can last for decades and are critical to each male's mating success,” the lead author of the study said. | Photo: Tim Clayton/Corbis via Getty Images

Insects are something of a miracle solution for an overfarmed, undernourished and meat-addicted world. With high levels of fat, protein, vitamins, fiber and mineral content, insects are often nutritionally comparable to, if not better than, fish and meat. Producing insects for food is also extremely cost-efficient and environmentally friendly. Rearing insects emits far less greenhouse gas, and they also need far less water, food and space to grow. The U.S. China relationship, for decades called the most important bilateral relationship on the planet, has all but collapsed. When China began opening itself to foreign investment, the money flowed in. China got steadily richer as economic reforms took hold. For American CEOS, the potential Chinese bonanza meant that U.S. policy toward Beijing had to revolve around nurturing— and expanding—the economic relationship. The big business community made it clear - first to the Clinton administration and then to his successor, George W. Bush - that trade with China was its highest priority. Over the last 30 years, prominent American companies have become part of the fabric of Chinese life and well before Donald Trump was elected, the carping about Beijing's policies from the Fortune 500 crowd intensified. Hit the link in the bio to read how America’s biggest companies made China great again. | Cover illustration by Alex Fine for Newsweek

Yunnan honey hunters in Dehong, China scale cliffs for “liquid gold.” These honey hunters stand on a makeshift rope ladder collecting honey while being surrounded by swarms of bees. Harvesting honey has been a long-standing tradition and economic staple for the Lisu, an ethnic group of people in the southwest mountainous areas of the Yunnan province. They are known to move skillfully in the mountains. While it is a long-standing tradition, more and more honey hunters are claiming to finding fewer hives due to environmental changes. Cliff honey typically sells for upwards of $50/kilogram in China and is considered more pure and healthier than regular honey. | Photo: Kevin Frayer/Getty Images

Scientists strapped cameras to penguins in Africa and found out that the animals dive deep into the ocean to drive their prey to the surface, enabling other seabirds to pick off the fish. The researchers attached equipment to 20 African penguins to learn about how seabirds feed, resulting in 31 hours of footage and a total of 57 dives. The footage was shot over a period of four breeding seasons between June to August 2015 and 2018. By watching these videos, the team learned about how deep and far the penguins swam, and the types of fish they caught. "This study shows that diving seabirds can play an important role in improving the foraging efficiency of other seabirds,” the author of the study said. African penguins are currently endangered. Studying how they find and catch their prey at sea will give us insights into how to best manage their prey supplies. | Photo: @emmett_sparling

After his comment about reparations were made at a press conference on Capitol Hill, Senator Mitch McConnell started to list ways in which he thought America has addressed slavery. “We’ve tried to deal with our original sin of slavery by fighting a civil war, by passing landmark civil rights legislation. We’ve elected an African American president,” he said. “I think we’re always a work in progress in this country but no one currently alive was responsible for that, and I don’t think we should be trying to figure out how to compensate for it.” McConnell’s comments were made a day before a historic hearing where the House of Representatives would convene a panel to discuss the continuing legacy of the trans-Atlantic slave trade for the first time in more than a decade. The panel will examine H.R. 40, a bill that would create a commission to study the history of slavery in the U.S. and make recommendations about how to educate the public. The hearing coincides with Juneteenth, which was established to commemorate the 1865 abolition of slavery in Texas. | Photo: Mark Wilson/Getty Images *

June 19 marks Juneteenth Day. While President Abraham Lincoln’s Emancipation Proclamation became effective in 1863, this did not affect slaves in Texas unless they escaped. Major General Gordon Granger arrived in Galveston, Texas on June 19 to enforce the Emancipation Proclamation. Formerly enslaved people in Galveston rejoiced in the streets when news broke out. In 1980, Texas established Juneteenth as a state holiday and in 2008 nearly half of the states observed the holiday as a ceremonial observance. It is the oldest known celebration commemorating the ending of slavery in the US. Hit the link in the bio for a guide of Juneteenth events and parades across America. | Photo: Mark Wilson/Getty Images

Why are yawns so contagious? As soon as you see someone yawning, you automatically find yourself doing the same. Scientists who prevented people from catching yawns in a study believe the reflex helps to cool down the brain. The team wanted to test their hypotheses that yawning is triggered when the skull gets too hot, and helps to cool the brain by taking warm blood away while bringing in a cooler supply. As expected, the scientists found cooling was linked to fewer yawn urges. "These findings are consistent with previous research indicating that yawns function as a compensatory brain cooling mechanism,” the authors wrote. | Photo: JUNG YEON-JE/AFP/GettyImages

On this day in 1884, the switchback railway made its debut as the first roller coaster in America when it opened in Brooklyn’s Coney Island. It was one of the earliest designed for any amusement parks in the U.S. The roller coaster went six miles per hour and only cost a nickel to ride. Today, the famous Cyclone roller coaster occupies where the switchback railway once stood. The historic wooden roller coaster opened in the summer of 1927 and is declared a New York City landmark. | Photo: Ben Hider/Getty Images

A study has found that around 96 percent of the 417 national parks evaluated have significant air pollution problems in at least one of four categories: unhealthy air; harm to nature; hazy skies; and climate change. The report—which was published by the National Parks Conservation Association(NPCA)—noted that 85 percent of parks have air that is unhealthy to breathe at times and 89 percent suffer from haze pollution. In fact, four of the most polluted parks—Joshua Tree, Mojave, Sequoia and Kings Canyon—had air pollution levels that were comparable, or sometimes even higher, than Los Angeles or Houston. “When people think of iconic parks like Joshua Tree or the Grand Canyon, they think of unspoiled landscapes and scenic views,” Theresa Pierno, NPCA’s President and CEO, said. “I think they would be shocked to know that these are actually some of our most polluted national parks. Despite the scale of the air pollution problem outlined in the report, the NPCA says there are clear solutions. These include transitioning to clean energy, defending clean air and climate laws, and holding polluters and the government to account. | Photo: @___floki___x *

It took 20 volunteers and five weeks to completely finish artist Bruce Munro’s fiber optic installation “Field of Light." Beautifully illuminating California’s wine country in waves of color, Munro’s latest art installation will not disappoint. Visitors heading to Paso Robles, California will be able to enjoy 58,800 stemmed spheres on 15 acres of land. Munro’s luminescent visions have appeared in Mexico, the U.K., and Australia, but this iteration is his largest to date. The artist dreams of seeing his fields on every continent, but not at the expense of their uniqueness. “I’ve turned down a few requests,” Munro said. “I’m protective and I don’t want to over-commercialize it. Did you know that only about a third of the world’s 246 longest rivers (those with a length greater than 600 miles) remain “free-flowing?" This reveals the extent to which humans are having an impact on the vital waterways that are the lifeblood of our planet. “A free-flowing river is [one that is] largely unaffected by human-made changes to its flow and connectivity. Water, silt, and fish can move along unobstructed,” Michele Thieme, an author of the study from World Wildlife Fund said. The biggest impact comes from physical barriers created by dams. The rivers are also affected by settlements, roads, and levees. “We believe that a first step towards the protection of free-flowing rivers is to identify them, and to monitor their status over time.” The planet’s remaining free-flowing rivers are now mostly restricted to remote regions of the Arctic, the Amazon Basin, and the Congo Basin, as well as a few areas in Southeast Asia.
| Photo: RHONA WISE/AFP/Getty Images

The Australian Koala Foundation said it believes “there are no more than 80,000 koalas in Australia,” making the species “functionally extinct.” Koalas are highly vulnerable to a variety of threats such as deforestation, disease, and the effects of climate change. Once a koala population falls below a critical point, it can no longer produce the next generation, leading to extinction. The term “functional extinct” can refer to a species whose population has declined to a point where it can no longer play a significant role in the ecosystem, a species that is suffering from inbreeding or describe a population that is no longer viable. The koala habitat continues to rapidly diminish, and unless it is protected, we will witness the wild koala population become “functionally extinct.” | Photo: TORSTEN BLACKWOOD/AFP/Getty Images *

NASA's planned mission to the moon, which aims to put the first woman on the lunar surface by 2024, has been named Artemis, after the ancient Greek goddess who was the daughter of Zeus and Leto. Artemis is the goddess of the moon as well as the twin sister of Apollo, whom NASA’s pioneering moon missions in the 1960s and 1970s were named after. NASA sees the 2024 Artemis mission as the first step toward the establishment of sustainable lunar surface missions by the late 2020s, as well as human exploration of Mars in the 2030s. “While there are many steps ahead in the budget and appropriations process, all of us at NASA should be very proud and excited by this unique opportunity,” NASA administrator Jim Bridenstine said. | Photo: Kevin Winter/Getty Images

Despite being one of the most radioactive areas on Earth, the Chernobyl Exclusion Zone attracts thousands of visitors each year. In 1986, A sudden power surge caused a breakdown at the Chernobyl nuclear power station in Ukraine, starting fires and releasing massive amounts of radiation into the environment. It’s estimated 115,000 people fled the most contaminated areas in the months following the accident, with another 220,000 leaving in the years to come. With little time to prepare, families left behind clothes, books, toys, and even pets. In 2011, the Ukrainian government opened the Exclusion Zone to tourists over the age of 18. Books are still piled up in empty classrooms and bumper cars are still rusting in an amusement park. Though there are still “hot” spots, officials insist radiation in most places have dropped below dangerous levels. There are even modest hotels for travelers looking for an overnight stay. Of course, visitors face strict security, body scans, and warning signs to avoid touching anything. Tag who you’d visit this new tourist attraction with. | Photo: @kreshman *

Morris, a traditional English folk dance, is usually performed to music while wearing bell pads on the shins and may involve sticks, swords or handkerchiefs. Chapel-en-le Frith Morris formed in 1975 and now allows women to join. “We dance because we’re happy,” the group’s website says. “We’re happy because we dance.” In honor of the Celtic festival of Beltane, members of the Chapel-en-le Frith Morris dance on Eccles Pike in the High Peak district of Derbyshire, England. | Photo: LINDSEY PARNABY/AFP/Getty Images

Bananas are one of the world’s most important crops, but in recent decades, the plant has been severely affected by a devastating fungal disease known as Black Sigatoka. According to a study, climate change has increased the infection risk of this disease by nearly 50 percent in banana-growing areas in Latin America and Caribbean. The fungal disease, which was imported to Honduras from Asia in 1972, infects the leaves and reduces productivity of the plant. Climate change is not the only factor behind the spread of Black Sigatoka. Increasing banana production and international trade also play an important role in the process. “The disease will get worse for regions that become wetter due to climate change,” Daniel Bebber, the author of the study told us. | Photo: lamiel/Getty Images Plus

Four Fijian communities have been forced to relocate from the effects of climate change. More than 80 communities have been earmarked by the Fiji government for potential future relocation. Low lying coastal communities are especially vulnerable to threats of sea-level rise, inundation of tides, increased intensity of storm surges, and coastal erosion. The impacts of climate change are set to rise, especially if global action to halt greenhouse gas emissions stagnates. While relocating communities to safer areas is an option to help manage climate hazards, it’s not a viable solution for all those affected. | Photo: TEVEN SAPHORE/AFP/Getty Images

Sexual assault is pervasive in our society and, for the most part, stays largely in the shadows. One reason is the societal shame and stigma that surrounds the victims of these crimes, and another is the way the traumatized brain operates. PTSD wreaks havoc on how the traumatized brain recalls and forgets, trauma scientists now refer to it as a disorder of memory. A PTSD sufferer can have trauma memories that are vivid, but at the same time infuriatingly vague. This paradox has been at the heart of the controversies that have surrounded PTSD and trauma survivors. By acknowledging the need to put memories back in order, survivors can restore harmony to the chaos of their memories and thrive in their new normal. | Photo: Nick Shepherd/Getty Images

Reef corals in the equatorial regions are going to start moving toward the poles as climate change takes hold, scientists have said. By analyzing the ranges of reefs from the fossil record, researchers are able to build a picture of how these systems respond to climate change and global warming. Findings show that reefs are likely to expand their poleward range—in both the Northern and Southern hemispheres—and decline in the regions they currently occupy. The move toward the poles in some species is already taking place. The next few decades will likely see a huge decline in biodiversity. Hit the link in the bio to read more. | Photo: hypergurl/Getty Images

There are five species of rhino, with three of them under threat of extinction. The last male northern white rhino, Sudan, died last year, leaving only two females of the subspecies alive. The West African black rhino was declared officially extinct in 2011. These deaths are due to habitat loss and big game hunters killing for sport. This day serves to draw attention to these magnificent animals and to bring awareness to the extremity of their vanishing existence in the wild. | Photo: PHILIPPE LOPEZ/AFP/Getty Images

Norwegian marine experts have encountered a beluga whale they believe has been trained by the Russian navy as part of a wider program of utilizing marine mammals in military operations. The whale was spotted in the Barents Sea where fishermen became suspicious when they saw that the animal was wearing a black harness and appeared to repeatedly seek out their boats. One of the fishermen said that the whale was trying to pull straps and ropes from the sides of the vessels and described the animal as very tame. The harness, which appeared configured to carry a camera, was retrieved from the whale with writing that read, “Equipment of St. Petersburg.” The Russian military is reportedly renewing its Cold War-era training of marine mammals, considering such animals useful tools in defending naval bases, assisting military divers and even attacking intruders. | Photo: Tim Clayton/Corbis via Getty Images

Are you adventurous enough to dine underwater? Under, a new subaquatic restaurant in Lindesnes, Norway, is housed in a 37-foot concrete shell and provides guests with a special dining experience. Guests will descend a flight of stairs to a room that only seats 40 people. They will then be seated by a giant aquarium-like window that opens to the North Sea, the perfect view for crystal jellyfish, pollack, crabs, anemones, seals, and more. Chef Nicolai Ellitsgaard Pederson is working with local fishermen and farmers to provide fresh sustainable ingredients that reflect the region’s cuisine. The eatery also doubles as a marine research facility, examining the diversity and behavior of the species living around the restaurant with an aim to maintain sustainable fishing. | Photo: Under Norway Restaurant

Greenland's ice sheet has melted over the past four decades and contributed to rising global sea levels, scientists have warned. From 1980 until 2018, the rate at which the ice was lost spiked sixfold. This culminated in a loss of approximately 290 gigatons (GT) per year between 2010 to 2018. In turn, this added 13.7 millimeters to sea levels, half of which happened over the past eight years. “If the Paris agreement targets are not met, then the Greenland ice sheet will very likely continue to lose mass in the future, impacting global sea level, ocean currents and regional climate,” Dr. Andrew Newton of the School of Earth and Environmental Sciences at The University of Manchester said. | 📸: @jaqdizzle *

Archaeologists in Egypt have uncovered an ancient tomb belonging to a high-ranking official that’s covered in colorful reliefs and well-preserved inscriptions. As weapons treaties unravel around the world, researchers are still studying the collateral damage of America’s first nuclear test. On July 16, 1945, the US Army exploded a plutonium bomb in the Jornada del Puerto desert in New Mexico also known as the Trinity test. As it turns out, the scientists who created and tested the bomb were unprepared for the extent of its fallout, as well as the repercussions from the explosion. Seven and a half decades later, we still lack any clear measurements of the environmental and health effects of the test and it will be years before any results are known. | Photo credit: US DEPARTMENT OF ENERGY/SCIENCE PHOTO LIBRARY/Getty *

We see plastic everywhere - on our coastlines, on the roads, in our parks, in our waters, and more. Since 1992, China has accepted 45% of the world’s total plastic recycling. Until, as of recently, they have decided to stop in an attempt to protect their own environment. Once touted as an indestructible magic material, plastics have a long and complex history. While plastic has had its positive influence in society, disposing of it is has been a global-threatening challenge. A study published in Scientific Advances estimates that by 2030 an estimated 111 million metric tons of plastic waste will be displaced because of China’s new law. From cleaning up and encouraging plastic-free solutions to supporting companies working with materials made from marine debris, there are many options in doing our part to help clean up our community. | 📷: Justin Sullivan/Getty Images

Feeling groggy? Sneak in a quick nap this weekend if you can. It’s easy to forget just how important sleep is for the brain and body. Essential processes go on in the brain that are necessary for it to perform at its best while sleeping. Michael Merzenich, professor and co-founder of Post Science, said that the brain basically rejuvenates itself and takes “out the garbage,” while your body essentially does the same. One important aspect to be aware of is that good sleep isn’t just about quantity, but quality. “You need to get enough sleep in time, but it’s also sleep quality. You need to go through this sleep cycling where the brain basically accomplishes these key things.” Going without these important features of sleep can lead to more than a day full of yawning. “It’s equivalent to accelerating the aging process in the brain.” | 📷: @theianwoo *

*

Scientists have discovered that Mars, the big red planet, once had huge rivers wider than the Mississippi river and it flowed intensely up until around one billion years ago. Research has shown that around 4 billion years ago, the planet had enough water to cover its surface in a 140 meter-deep liquid layer. Equal Pay Day is dedicated to raising awareness of the gender pay gap and symbolizes how far into the year women must work to earn what men earned the year before. Out of 149 countries, the U.S. ranked 51st in terms of making progress toward gender parity in 2018. Last year, the World Economic Forum's (WEF) Global Gender Gap Report estimated that it will take 202 years to close the gender gap. While the U.S. has made some “modest improvements” in economic opportunity and participation, progress toward gender parity has been delayed by a “directional reversal” in education and political empowerment. | 📷: Joe Raedle/Newsmakers *

April Fool’s Day is a day for tricksters to show off their creativity in the form of jokes and pranks. The first of April is known worldwide as the day to put your guard up and not be so gullible from the mass spread of hoaxes and harmless antics. The first April Fool’s Day can actually be dated back to ancient Rome and has been practiced in places like France, Switzerland, and more. The aurora borealis stunningly displays its lights over the skies in the southern part of Norway. You can only catch this light display around the magnetic poles of the northern and southern hemispheres. Collisions between electrically charged particles that are released by the sun, collide with gases like oxygen and nitrogen upon entering the earth’s atmosphere to create this spectacle.

The light display can appear in many forms, from small patches to shooting rays that fill up the night. (📷: HEIKO JUNGE/AFP/Getty Images)

Happy Birthday to the Grand Canyon. President Theodore Roosevelt designated the Grand Canyon a National Park one hundred years ago.

To celebrate America's most iconic park, "The Grand Canyon: Between River and Rim" by Pete McBride shows a look inside the National Park through stunning photography.

An exerpt from the book describes how amazing it is, but a lot goes into truly understanding the Grand Canyon. "There is simply nothing like it. Sadly, most people only see it from up high, from a crowded “scenic lookout.” They peer down into the abyss, dutifully awestruck and mystified. Then they hop back in their cars. It’s grand all right, but there’s just too much there: too much to take in, too much to see and think about, too much to feel." (📷: Pete McBride @pedromcbride )

This week's issue highlights Newsweek's 2019 Blockchain Impact Awards. We set out to spotlights the promise of disruptive ideas in #blockchain, drawing on our nearly century long heritage of covering the world and the forces and movements that shape it. Flip through to meet the five winners: SimplyVital Health, BitLumens, Chronicled, Prescrypto and Grassroots Economics. Click the link in our bio for the full story. 
1) SimplyVital Health: The healthcare industry is ripe for a blockchain inspired transformation, and SimplyVital Health is leading the charge.

2) BitLumens: What does renewable energy have to do with poverty and access to the financial system? Plenty, according to BitLumens, a Swiss company that uses blockchain to help get people on the power grid, build their credit profiles and reduce carbon emissions.

3) Chronicled: Chronicled is developing a blockchain based solution to supply chain management, recording all of the transactions that take place as pharmaceuticals travel from factory to container to shelf.

4) Prescrypto: Prescrypto provides a blockchain-based infrastructure to collect prescribing information, route that information securely to pharmacies, and provide a history of medications used by each patient. 
5) Grassroots Economics: Grassroots Economics is challenging the idea that banks should have a monopoly on currency. (Illustrations: Geo Law @geolaw)

Yosemite National Park is stunning year-round, but February is known for a phenomenon called “The Firefall." Only a few weeks a year provide enough abundant snowfall for the setting sun to illuminate this area of Horsetail Falls, which causes the waterfall to glow with such intensity it appears to be on fire.

February is the only time of year that this magic can be captured, and many factors are involved. Intrepid photographers who capture this amazing work of Mother Nature must struggle to find the right spot at the right time, with some hiking for hours in waist-deep snow. The challenge seems to encourage the bold, with thousands of hopeful photographers flocking to the falls to witness, and capture, this breathtaking event. (📷: Felipe Silva @the_lost_coast )

From our 1/25 issue, here’s a closer look at the 🌙 moon, by the numbers:

12 ➡️ Number of astronauts who have walked on the moon; 24 have orbited it. 💲145 billion ➡️ Amount spent, in 2018 money, on the Apollo program ($25.4 billion in 1973). By comparison, the U.S. has spent $100 billion on the International Space Station.

220,400 ➡️ Amount of fuel, in pounds, to power vehicles leaving the lunar surface from a base.

59% ➡️ Portion of the moon’s surface we can see from Earth.

27 ➡️ Number of days it takes for the moon to rotate on its axis—the same time it takes to orbit the Earth, which is why we always see the same side.

⅙ ➡️ The moon’s gravity compared with Earth’s. 💲1,360 ➡️ The price of 1 pound of rocket fuel delivered to a spaceship in low-Earth orbit.

1,550 ➡️ Number of miles across the South Pole-Aitken Basin, the largest and oldest crater on the moon.

30 ➡️ Percentage of the lunar “regolith” in the cold, dark bottom of some craters that is made up of ice. (📷: Parameter/Getty Images)

One of the thorniest problems that humankind faces in the coming decades is how to feed a global population that is expected to grow by 3.6 billion people by century's end. To keep up with demand, food production will have to double by 2050, according to the UN. That's going to be a tall order. The worst effects of climate change on agriculture have yet to kick in, and arable land is getting scarcer. Already more than 800 million people go hungry each day.

A breakthrough in Agriculture science could solve this crisis—But will the public accept it? 
Swipe right to get the full picture, and click the link in our bio for more. (🖼: Andrzej Wojcicki/Science Photo Library/Getty)

In the shadow of the Cairngorm mountains nestled deep in the Scottish Highlands, a sled dog looks on. It’s time for The Siberian Husky Club of Great Britain’s 36th Aviemore Sled Dog Rally. 
The annual two-day race attracts mushers from across the U.K. to race along the idyllic forest trails around Loch Morlich in Aviemore, Scotland. Dog sled teams of up to eight dogs pull their musher on four-to-seven mile long routes. No snow? No problem. Dogs will pull their musher on a three-wheeled rig, instead. (📷: ANDY BUCHANAN/AFP/Getty Images)

33 years ago today, the Space Shuttle #Challenger exploded just 73 seconds after liftoff. All seven crew members, five NASA astronauts and two payload specialists, were killed in the explosion. The February 10, 1986 cover of Newsweek asked the question that was no doubt on the minds of many Americans that winter: ‘What Went Wrong?’ “Following the disaster, a presidential commission investigation of the accident found that a flame had burned through the shuttle’s external tank and ruptured a liquid-hydrogen tank milliseconds before the right booster smashed into the liquid-oxygen tank. As a result, the two liquids mixed and exploded, consuming the challenger.” Click the link in our bio for more.

Ice Cave	Trekking inside the Mendenhall Glacier is like entering a world made of gemstones. Located in Juneau, Alaska, the glacier is constantly moving and flowing, periodically creating caves like this one along its edge, which, while dangerous, are also visually stunning with photos appearing to be heavily photoshopped – but aren’t. The many blues are actually from light filtering through the ice at different thicknesses and directions, while the reddish color is the earth illuminated by the light from the mouth of the cave. Mont Saint Michel was originally a monastery founded in the 8th century on the coast of Normandy in France, which, due to its strategic location and natural defenses, was later developed into an impregnable fortress. As it’s built on a mountain that is completely surrounded by a tidal flat, it is totally surrounded by water during high tide, and at low tide it is surrounded by mud - making both land and water sieges nearly impossible. These days, the island-city is an @unesco World Heritage Site and isn’t so much about keeping invaders out as it is about getting tourists in – and so there is a modern causeway which allows people to drive to the island at anytime. Go now while you still can: The Canadian Wildlife service estimates only 800 polar bears currently roam their wilderness and has proclaimed the species as threatened under The Endangered Species Act. According to researchers in the area, the bear situation is so fragile as although there's been early freezes the last two years, on the average over the last 20 years the summers have gotten longer meaning less time on the ice, less food and less viable pregnancies. Fifteen years ago, they used to see a lot of twin or triplet cubs, which is now rare as most females can only support a single cub. Globally, the bears are under threat due to Global Warming and habitat loss as the polar ice cap melts and bears either have to swim farther for food or enter human villages (where they are most often shot to preserve human life). The best place to see polar bears in the wild is Churchill, Manitoba, due to the ice conditions. The currents in Hudson Bay flow counterclockwise, meaning cold water from the north flow towards the shelf of land which juts out into the bay. At this point is the mouth of the Churchill River, which brings fresh water into the bay, raising the freezing point of the water and making it a hangout for the polar bears in the area who wait for the ice to freeze so they can hunt seals in the winter. Emporer penguins gather at South Georgia Island, a remote and inhospitable island in the far southern fringe of the Atlantic Ocean near Antarctica. 
According to our guest photographer, @everythingeverywhere: “I am often asked what my favorite place in the world is. While there is no real answer to the question, I will often reply ‘South Georgia Island. South Georgia is like no place on Earth. There is no permanent human population on the island and the island is mostly inhabited by seals and penguins. Lots and lots of penguins. It is one of the largest penguin breeding colonies in the world. The Penguins also have no fear of humans and will walk right up to you. It also gained fame as the location where Ernest Shackleton sailed out to in a rowboat to rescue his crew.” [For the next few months, Newsweek will be featuring the work of several photographers doing interesting work around the globe and highlighting places, people and stories that we don't hear enough about. Some people go to Fiji or Miami for their honeymoon, but not photographer @30.raw. He and his wife spent the weeks after their wedding in Mauritania and then decided to hop on the longest train in the world which is roughly 2 miles long and carries iron ore from the middle of the Sahara Desert to the Atlantic Ocean. "We camped out on top of the iron ore for 17 hours while temperatures reached as high as 50 Celsius during the day and dropped to near freezing during the evening. Some of the areas the train passed through used to be infiltrated by Al Qaeda rebels and are still sprinkled with landmines. Although it's not a passenger train, locals tend to jump on top and ride it across the Sahara as it’s the only viable option for transportation across the vast desert. Bandits are something to be aware of as well and not to be taken too lightly. Not the safest trip but extremely adventurous with breathtaking scenery." . . . .

Two elephants walk side by side in the Masai Mara in Kenya – lucky to still be alive. Although elephant hunts were banned in the 1970s, the pachyderms are still on the brink of extinction due to the demand for ivory in China and SouthEast Asia – with up to 55 elephants per day being slaughtered by poachers. According to the Kenya Star newspaper, “​The overall number of elephants has declined by about one third over the last decade... [They] now live in small and isolated populations. And should the current trends persist, elephants will be wiped out in the next decade.” ​​[​For the next few months, ​Newsweek will be featuring the work of several photographers doing interesting work around the globe and highlighting places, people and stories that we don't hear enough about. ​This week we are featuring photos taken by award-winning photographer Susan Portnoy of the ​​@insatiabletraveler]​

A long abandoned trading post in the ghost town of Silver City, near Kluane National Park in Yukon, Canada. ​The Kluane Lake area was the site of a short-lived gold rush in the early 1900s. But by 1914 it was clear there wasn’t as much gold to be found as first thought and the town of Silver City was slowly abandoned. Today it sits as a reminder of what once was – and a haunting reminder of the thousands who came to work the inhospitable area and left with almost nothing. ​[​For the next few months, ​Newsweek will be featuring the work of several photographers doing interesting work around the globe and

A portrait ​of a Himba woman, nicknamed Krocodile after surviving a crocodile attack ​over a decade ago​. ​At the time of this photo (2015), she was 42 and had 13 children. Taken in northern Namibia in the Skeleton Coast near Angola​. ​The Himba people are a nomadic, desert tribe living in Namibia – there are only 50,000 ​remaining​ and they are considered a “disappearing” culture. They are most recognizable by their distinctive hairstyles which are created using a mixture of butterfat and ochre and is used not only as a protection against the sun but to keep the skin clean during the long dry seasons. It also helps to ward off mosquitos and other insects. The Himba, backed by International human rights groups, are battling their government against a proposed Dam along the Kunene River, which they say would be destructive to their ancestral grounds. ​[​For the next few months, ​Newsweek will be featuring the work of several photographers doing interesting work around the globe and highlighting places, people and stories that we don't hear enough about. ​This week we are featuring photos taken by award-winning photographer Susan Portnoy of the ​@insatiabletraveler]

The sun sets on one of the 3,000 temples in Old Bagan, Myanmar. The country opened up for tourism in 2012​ – but since 2017, tourism has suffered due to the Rohingya Crisis, in which nearly 700,000 have fled the destruction of their homes and persecution in the northern Rakhine province of Myanmar. The ​“Asian Mandela”, Aung San Suu Kyi, ​ a Nobel Peace Prize winner who lived under house arrest for many years for her pro-democracy activism (and currently a “state counsellor”), stayed silent about what some are calling a genocide - until September when she announced at the World Economic Forum: “​There are of course ways in which we, with hindsight, might think that the situation could have been handled better... But we believe that for the sake of long-term stability and security we have to be fair to all sides. The rule of law must apply to everybody. We cannot choose and pick whom should be protected by rule of law.” The Rohingya fled – and so did the tourists. It remains to be seen if either will come back. ​[​For the next few months, ​Newsweek will be featuring the work of several photographers doing interesting work around the globe and highlighting places, people and stories that we don't hear enough about. ​This week we are featuring photos taken by award-winning photographer Susan Portnoy of the @​ insatiabletraveler​]

A polar bear takes a nap on Hudson Bay in Northern Manitoba, Canada. The Canadian Wildlife service estimates only 800 polar bears currently roam their wilderness and has proclaimed the species as threatened under The Endangered Species Act. According to researchers in the area, the bear situation is so fragile as although there's been early freezes the last two years, on the average over the last 20 years the summers have gotten longer meaning less time on the ice, less food and less viable pregnancies. Fifteen years ago, they used to see a lot of twin or triplet cubs, which is now rare as most females can only support a single cub. Globally, the bears are under threat due to Global Warming and habitat loss as the polar ice cap melts and bears either have to swim farther for food or enter human villages (where they are most often shot to preserve human life). The daughter of an eagle hunter looks on in the Altai Mountains of Mongolia. Eagle hunting is a 4,000 year old art which has remained unchanged throughout the ages. Eagles are trained to hunt marmot, fox, wolf as well as rabbits, mountain goats and other animals. While eagle hunting is used in Kazakhstan, Mongolia and throughout the Middle East, only the Kazakhs in the Altai mountain region use the golden eagle to hunt. While it is mainly a male sport, women are slowly starting to integrate into the nomadic family tradition. In 2016, Aisholpan, a Mongolian teen was documented in the film “The Eagle Huntress” fighting to become the first woman in 12 generations to join the hunt. For the next few months, Newsweek will be featuring the work of several photographers doing interesting work around the globe and highlighting stories that we don't get to hear enough about. This week is award-winning photographer Susan Portnoy of the @insatiabletraveler, whose first photo for us is a mesmerizing portrait of Rockfig Jr., a leopardess, resting after gorging on an impala inside the Timbavati Private Nature & Game Reserve in South Africa. According to a 2016 press release from the center for biological diversity, "Leopards are at risk of extinction across their African and Asian range, having suffered a population decline in sub-Saharan Africa of more than 30 percent in the past 25 years, in part due to unsustainable trophy hunting by Americans. Yet due to a loophole in place since 1982, hundreds of leopard trophies per year have been imported into the United States without proper scrutiny by the federal government or scientific experts. In 2014, hunters imported 311 leopard trophies into the United States. In sub-Saharan Africa, the leopard population has declined by more than 30 percent in the past 25 years, and the species has lost 48 to 67 percent of its historic range in Africa." .

While the race to plant tourists on the moon is on, some are now speculating that Mars could be next. While the unmanned Mars Curiosity Rover has been rumbling over the landscape, Elon Musk and SpaceX team thinks manned ships could be next, despite the fact that t​ he ​red planet's atmosphere is almost entirely made up of carbon dioxide​. But ​Vasco Guerra​, a physicist at the University of Lisbon in Portugal, who's been ​using plasma to break down carbon dioxide​ here on Earth, has started wondering whether the same technology might have interplanetary uses. "At first we were discussing it like a kid’s game, "he says in an email to​Newsweek. "But the more we thought about it, the better the idea looked." But not everyone is keen to place men on Mars. ​Bill Anders, who was the lunar module pilot for NASA's Apollo 8 mission, told​ BBC Radio 5 Live that sending crews to the Red Planet would be "almost ridiculous." “What's the imperative? What's pushing us to go to Mars?" Anders, 85, ​said​, adding: "I don't think the public is that interested." Respectfully, we disagree. For more information on this story click link in bio. (Credit:
Vac1/@gettyimages)

This 1952 Beech airplane was the first plane to land at the Bluie East 2 Airforce base in over 30 years. Traveling across the Arctic as part of the @vintageairrally last summer, owners Phil and Allie Dunnington along with their pilot John Herbert were able to inspect the crumbling base first hand. Built by the Americans in World War 2, it was abandoned by 1958 and today, considerable environmental damage has been done ​from the thousands of rusted fuel drums, vehicles, and ruins left behind. The need for a clean-up has been an occasional political issue - resolved (at least financially) by an agreement mid 2017 between the Danish and Greenland governments. Clean up finally started this year. ​For more information on this story click link in bio. (​Credit: ​@pfro)

This week Japan announced it will resume ​commercial whaling in its waters for the first time in three decades next summer, following plans to leave the International Whaling Commission (IWC). By leaving the IWC, Japan steps back from the body’s founding document, the International Convention for the Regulation of Whaling, ​which was signed in 1946.​ In 1986, the IWC's moratorium on whaling took effect, which put an end to commercial hunting of all whale species.
Japan had frequently cited “scientific purposes” to take advantage of an IWC loophole to kill hundreds of the mammals each year, according to ​Japan Times​. Humpback whales, like the one pictured here, are the most popular for Japanese - and often end up on dinner plates across the country. For more information on this story click link in bio. (Credit: @gettyimages)

The Darul Aman Palace is located just 16 km outside of Kabul, Afghanistan. Designed by German architect Walter Harten, the Palace was constructed in the 1920s by the then King, Amanullah Khan - and was to be the center of a new modern city called Darulaman that would have been connected to Kabul by a light rail. Amanullah was forced from power in 1929 and since then, the building has suffered through several fires, and housed mujahedeen, the Taliban, as well as American soldiers. ​In 2005, a plan was unveiled to refurbish the palace for use as the seat of Afghanistan's future parliament, but work was halted when it became one of several targets in a series of attacks launched on April 15, 2012, for which the ​Taliban​ claimed responsibility. Restoration was once again resumed in 2016 and by February 2018, almost 50 percent of the renovation was complete. ​For more information on this story click link in bio. ​Pictures of the Palace were taken in 2014 by @pfro.

​According to the Christian religion, 2,018 years ago today, Jesus was born in Bethlehem, Palestine. The spot where the manger where Mary and Joseph are believed to have taken shelter is now the Church of the Nativity. C​ommissioned in 327 by ​Constantine the Great​ and his mother ​Helena​, it was completed around 339 - but destroyed in a fire over one hundred years later. George H.W. Bush, the 41st president of the United States, died at the age of 94 on Friday. From 1987 to 1992, Newsweek featured first the vice president and then later president on its cover four times. Perhaps one of the most controversial covers—on October 19, 1987, right after Bush had announced he was running for president—questioned his strength as a politician and presidential candidate, calling Bush's greatest challenge his "wimp factor." Not quite a year later, in the August 22, 1988 issue, Newsweek interviewed the now-nominated Republican candidate on his strategy to defeat Democrat Michael Dukakis. Next, a few months later in November, a deep dive into "How Bush Won" with "The Inside Story of Campaign '88" was on the cover. Finally, in the issue dated December 10, 1990—two years into Bush's first and only presidential term—Newsweek's cover quoted the president's speech announcing war on Iraq: "This will not be another Vietnam." The last "Bush" Newsweek cover was on March 30, 1992, which featured a picture not of the sitting president, but of a young Bill Clinton with the text: "Can He Beat Bush?" 01. Featured on the cover of the August 22, 1988 issue, Newsweek interviewed then-Republican candidate George H.W. Bush on his strategy to defeat Democrat Michael Dukakis. (Newsweek/ Photo by Michael O'Neill)

02. Featured on the cover of the October 19, 1987 issue, Perhaps one of the most controversial covers, right after Bush had announced he was running for president—questioned his strength as a politician and presidential candidate, calling Bush's greatest challenge his "wimp factor." George H. W. Bush, the 41st president of the United States, passed away at the age of 94. His death comes less than eight months after the passing of his wife, Barbara Bush. The late-night announcement of his passing by his son George W. Bush, the 43rd president of the United States, sparked an outpouring of tributes honoring his life of public service.

After months of travel through space, the InSight lander, short for Interior Exploration using Seismic Investigations, Geodesy and Heat Transpot, that was bound for Mars finally made its arrival on the surface of the red planet Monday. Its findings will improve understanding about the evolution of our inner solar system's rocky planets, including Earth.

01: Rendering of Mars (Stocktrek Images/Getty)

02. NASA engineers on the flight team, Kris Bruvold (L) and Sandy Krasner (R) celebrate the InSight spacecraft's successful landing on the planet Mars from the Mission Support area in the Space Flight Operations facility at the NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) in Pasadena, California on November 26, 2018. - Cheers and applause erupted at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory as a $993 million unmanned lander, called InSight, touched down on the Red Planet and managed to send back its first picture. (Al Seib/AFP/Getty Images)

03. This artist's concept from August 2015 depicts NASA's InSight Mars lander fully deployed for studying the deep interior of Mars. (NASA)

04. The NASA InSight spacecraft launches onboard a United Launch Alliance Atlas-V rocket on May 5, 2018, from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. - NASA on May 5 launched its latest Mars lander, called InSight, designed to perch on the surface and listen for "Marsquakes" ahead of eventual human missions to explore the Red Planet. (Robyn Beck/AFP/Getty Images)

“Everything that’s happened has been unexpected,” Josh Groban says of his career. As a teenager, he studied acting, but that high lyric baritone could not be denied: By 2007, was the No.1 pop artist in the U.S., thanks in part to his 2003 hit “You Raise Me Up.” In 2015, he was offered a starring role in the Broadway musical Natasha, Pierre & the Great Comet of 1812, an electro-pop adaptation of War and Peace, and that earned him a Tony nomination. Now, a few TV cameos (The Office, Crazy Ex-Girlfriend) over the years have evolved into his own show, Netflix’s The Good Cop, from Monk creator Andy Breckman. Groban plays Tony “TJ” Caruso, a by-the-book New York City police officer; Tony Danza co-stars as his dad, a disgraced ex-cop. The series debuts on September 21, which also happens to be the release date for Groban’s eighth studio album, Bridges. “The timing was perfect,” he says of Good Cop’s four-month shoot. “It fit right between finishing the album and going on tour [beginning October 18]. When I was done, I got to grow my beard out and make music again.” (illustration by @britt.spencer for Newsweek)

He’s been pushing the boundaries of comedy on his eponymous Adult Swim show since 2012—and pushing hard. Andre’s delusional, sociopathic talk show–host persona drops his guests into what critics have called a “torture chamber” of organized chaos: often disgusting, occasionally disarming and pretty much always exasperating to the likes of Jimmy Kimmel or Krysten Ritter, or unsuspecting folk on the street. In one segment, he stripped down to a thong made of peanut butter in a New York City park. As an actor, he’s a little tamer, with regular sitcom work (Don’t Trust the B— in APT 23, Man Seeking Woman) and, as of August 17, his own character in Matt Groening’s latest animated show, the adult comedy-fantasy series Disenchantment. Andre plays Luci, a nihilistic “personal demon” to Abbi Jacobson’s boozy medieval princess Bean. “It’s somewhere on the spectrum between The Simpsons and Monty Python,” Andre tells Newsweek. “It’s Groening’s attempt at Game of Thrones.” (Illustration by @britt.spencer for Newsweek)

For more than six decades, U.S. presidents had a hard and fast rule when it came to North Korea: Don’t meet with a dictator. The mere image of the leader of the free world standing with an authoritarian figure would bestow prestige and legitimacy on a rogue state—one that has flouted U.N. sanctions, assassinated political rivals and built a small nuclear arsenal. Then, on June 12, Donald Trump burned the playbook. With full swagger, the president swept into steamy Singapore, where he sat down with Kim Jong Un in an unprecedented bid to get him to, as he put it, “de-nuke.” Afterward, Trump mocked the criticism that his presence alone had given the young dictator something precious. #RedCarpet (Illustration by @alexfineillos for Newsweek)

Last November, Brooklyn-based comic Hari Kondabolu launched The Problem With Apu, a documentary that questioned the racial legacy of Simpsons character Apu Nahasapeemapetilon, described by Kondabolu as “a white guy doing an impression of a white guy making fun of my father.” It was a way into the larger issue of how minorities are represented in the press, and the doc sparked heated, widespread discussions on social media. It also prompted Hank Azaria, the white actor who is the voice Apu, to say he was “perfectly willing and happy” to give up the role. (Simpsons creator Matt Groening, meanwhile, continues to shrug off criticism.) Illustration for Newsweek by @britt.spencer

Michael Wolff’s ‘Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House’ is reportedly based on more than 200 interviews with President Donald J. Trump and his inner circle. One of the book’s key figures is former White House chief strategist Steve Bannon. According to Wolff, Bannon described the infamous Trump Tower meeting set up by Donald Trump Jr. as “treasonous” and “unpatriotic.” “They’re going to crack Don Junior like an egg on national TV,” Bannon allegedly said. After Bannon’s quotes surfaced, the president responded by saying his former confidant “lost his mind” after being fired from the White House. Are Republicans teetering on the edge? Will Trump’s White House ever fully recover from the fire and the fury? (Photograph for Newsweek by @gregkahn)

At a elementary school turned shelter in the central park of the island, Elba Ramos Jayuya and her Ex-husband have lived along with 6 members of her family for more than two months. Their home was completely destroyed in the hurricane, and there is nothing to return to. Displacement has been a major effect of the storm, and a generalized effect of climate change and global warming. 
In the second picture, mountains of belongings from people’s homes and lives sit bulldozed into piles in the central part of the island. Waste is already an enormous problem for island infrastructure management, but the storm has added enormous weight to an already strained system. (@joshuacogan for the @who)
This past week, I had the opportunity to travel to Puerto Rico with the World Health Organization to do some documentation of the post hurricane recovery. It was a short trip, just a few days really, and in such a short period of time, doing justice to any experience or telling of someone else’s experience is fraught with ignorance and assumptions. There are elements you can learn from being in conversation with people, and some you can from witnessing, but there is also a language of heart that goes beyond the words and thoughts. Now 70 days past the devastating hurricane, the immediate trauma has past, and the long-term work of repair is setting in. (6/6)

As I turned around, I saw neighborhood residents Josefina Hernandez Serrano and Jose Soto (first image), who were taking a break from trying to salvage what they could of their homes, to survey the status of the neighborhood. According to them, many of the residents had departed for good, feeling there was nothing left to save, and of those that returned, many are older, with no other options for housing. 
As I was wandering around photographing in Toa Baja City, I found it difficult to visually capture the scale of destruction. This downed tree over this house (second image) seemed to convey that in a way that other images couldn’t. Huge and mighty, the soil became so saturated, even it’s roots could not maintain grip. It toppled over directly on top of the home of Victor Sierra. (@joshuacogan for the @who)

There are elements you can learn from being in conversation with people, and some you can from witnessing, but there is also a language of heart that goes beyond the words and thoughts. Now 70 days past the devastating hurricane, the immediate trauma has past, and the long-term work of repair is setting in. (5/6)

The people that remained, are heartbroken, all they had has been lost. In conversation with them, it becomes clear that PTSD has set in, as despite their best efforts to salvage what is left, there is very little to build upon. They are without power, water, roofs, and in many cases any of their belongings. One resident pictured here, Eliseo Nunez Ruiz (first image) told us he was doing his best to not visualize his own suicide, but he felt he was losing the battle.
One of the days, we followed some local health care workers to Toa Baja City, a area on the northern coast, built on the alluvial deposits of the three rivers that flow nearby. There isn’t much intellectualization that can describe what happened there, and the only words that come to mind is destruction. Pure and absolute. Flood waters rose 15-20 feet, filling first then the second floor (second image). Many of the residents have just left, the keys sit in the flooded cars, the homes emptied, doors left open, plants begin to grow over everything and bulldozers just push the destroyed remnants of people’s belongings into piles so more disaster relief crews can move through the streets. (@joshuacogan for the @who)

Looking at the land is like looking at the people, as both are shell shocked. Every leaf on every tree of the island was blown away, mighty trees snapped in half or the soil they were rooted in so saturated they just fell over. In El Yunque National Park in the center of the island, the dense old growth rainforest, with it’s thick forest canopy, looks as if a giant sickle swung across the land. A few trees per hectare left standing, the rest blown over or broken from the intense winds. The park has been closed since the storm, for the longest period it ever has been since its founding. As bright sunlight reaches to the ground as never before, the ecology of the forest floor is greatly affected, giving rise to new interplay between species. Further, much of the research infrastructure at the Sabina Station at the Institute for Tropical Forestry has been destroyed as well, with towers pushed over, and monitoring sites covered with downed trees and brush. (@joshuacogan for the @who)

The extent of the damage from hurricane Maria could take hundreds of years to repair according to Aura Alonso, Project Manager and Researcher at the Institute for Tropical Forestry (first image). Talking to the people who work there does not also come without tears. They see the effects of climate change and the storms more directly than anyone, and there is great reason for concern. As natural resources are degraded, marshes and mangroves destroyed, and sea levels rise...a dangerous situation is in the making.
Soil Samples from Sabana Research Station, in El Yunque sit ready for lab testing (second image). El Yunque is possibly one of the most studied tropical forests in the world, home to 23 tree species only found in the park and several animal species as well. Here, researchers have been studying the effects of Climate Change on Tropical Forest Ecology for several years, often trying to mimic the conditions of a hurricane on sample sites. Maria brought the value of that research into view as never before. 
At a minimum, El Yunque provides 20% of the water that Puerto Rico uses, with 8 of the major rivers serving the island originating here. (@joshuacogan for the @who)

Toa Baja City was one of the hardest hit areas during Hurricane Maria, as enormous flooding swept into the neighborhood raising water levels some 15-20 feet above normal levels. Residents and relief crews are just beginning to be able to access much of the area, as the flood waters have receded. Many of the residents have spent several months at shelters, just to come back to see so little left.
In the first image, Enrique Gonzalez stands behind his home looking over the one of the many rivers that surround Toa Baja. The area was built on the alluvial deposits of the rivers, and as the land has been slowly degraded over time, so has its ability to retain water when intense rains come. As the water rose in their home Enrique moved his wife and grandaughter up to the second floor, and then on top of a freezer as the water kept getting higher. With no end in sight, Enrique said goodbye to his family believing they would all drown. Miraculously, a neighbor was able to get through the 2nd floor entryway with a small boat and save them. They just returned after 2 months in a shelter to the neighborhood, to find almost nothing left of their home. In the second image, a rosary hangs from a rearview mirror in an abandoned van. The vehicle sat completely underwater for a length of time, and the cracked mud forms looks like tile mosaics on the interior. Similar to the experience of visiting Pompeii, you can see that life just stopped suddenly and without warning as the water rose. (@joshuacogan for the @who)

We recently caught up with #SebastianGorka and asked him: What gives you the confidence that Trump will decide he’s better off returning to his original allies?

The president has a very interesting management style. He’s comfortable with unusually high levels of creative chaos beneath him, because he sees who’s the best fighter and who makes the best argument. But if he feels he’s being poorly served by his lieutenants, he allows that frustration to increase until he gets to a point where he takes decisive action. I predict he will take decisive action to get [rid of] those people around him who are not serving his original platform. That’s just how he works. I predict that there will be some firings in the near future that come from the president himself when he realizes just how much he needs the old team to be around him. I’m not making any predictions about Steve and myself. Whether or not Steve goes back or I go back—this is the long game. We’re in this for eight years and then eight years of President Pence. (🎨by @joeciardiello)
