Love That Hurts (5/5): Chimone, 14, poses with her mother, who began sending her to her grandmother to have her breasts ironed two months before this image was taken. Chimone's grandmother is responsible for ironing the breasts of six girls, including Chimone's cousins and neighbors. “When you look from outside, you feel like it is criminal. How could they do that to their daughters?” says photographer Heba Khamis. But it’s more complicated than a Western observer might immediately see. “[It’s]a mother who’s trying to show love, to protect her daughter. I can see love, but also how it’s hurting” | Photo by @heba__khamis

Love That Hurts (4/5): Fabiola, 11, poses after having her breasts ironed. She has endured the practice twice a day for three months. The victims of breast ironing are usually between 8 and 12 years old. Girls in Cameroon are reaching puberty earlier and marrying later, and many mothers want to make sure their daughters don’t get pregnant and miss out on opportunities to go to school and get jobs | Photo by @heba__khamis

Love That Hurts (3/5): A stone is heated on a hot grill after cooking. The tools used for breast ironing vary from village to village. The painful process is usually performed by the mother or a close female relative of a young girl and begins with heating a hard object, usually a stone or a wooden spoon. The object is then pressed against the breast, sometimes multiple times a day, melting the fat and causing the breast to recede | Photo by @heba__khamis

Love That Hurts (2/5): Veronica, 28, massages the breasts of her 10-year-old daughter, Michelle, as her other children watch. Veronica started to iron Michelle's breasts seven months before this image was taken. Her older daughter, not pictured, refused to have her breasts ironed and had a baby at the age of 15 | Photo by @heba__khamis

Love That Hurts (1/5): Kamini, 12, hides her breasts after her mother ironed them. Nearly a quarter of the women in Cameroon, a Central African nation of 23 million, have endured some form of breast ironing. Many Cameroonian mothers believe that by flattening their daughters' breasts, they can protect them from men who would otherwise make sexual advances or rape them | Photo by @heba__khamis

Cancer Rebels (4/4): Tom Marsilje poses in San Diego on July 12. In 2012, Marsilje was diagnosed with stage III colorectal cancer. He created a spreadsheet of clinical trials that was later released as an app to help cancer patients find the trials that would offer them hope | Photo by @miss_ramona for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Cancer Rebels (3/4): Matthew Zachary poses in the meeting room of Stupid Cancer's office in Tribeca, New York, on July 10. Zachary, 43, a classically trained pianist, was in his senior year of college when his left hand stopped working. Doctors soon diagnosed him with a brain tumor and gave him six months to live. Today, Zachary is the founder and CEO of Stupid Cancer—an advocacy and support organization for Generation X and millennial cancer patients and survivors. “I’m pissed and you're pissed, and that’s kind of cool, because we can be pissed together” | Photo by @eriktanner for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Cancer Rebels (2/4): Tamika Felder speaks at a consultation in Upper Marlboro, Maryland on July 11. Felder, a cervical cancer survivor and advocate, underwent punishing treatments that made her lose her fertility. “You don’t feel like a woman. You don’t feel like anybody will ever want you…. And being 25, I was like, ‘I’m gonna have to give up sex for the rest of my life!’” says Felder. “I wanted to know, is this it for me?” She eventually founded Cervivor, a nonprofit that helps patients and survivors of cervical cancer to heal and thrive | Photo by @gregkahn for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Cancer Rebels (1/4): Landon Riddle, 7, uses a vape pen on July 10 at home in Colorado. Landon was diagnosed with an aggressive form of leukemia as a toddler. After watching her son undergo lifesaving treatment that appeared to be killing him, Sierra Riddle chose to treat her child with cannabis. Landon became the youngest patient in the United States to receive a medical marijuana card | Photo by Ryan David Brown for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Brienne of Tarth (2/2): “Even when I was very young, I didn’t understand why the women had to have the boring parts,” says Gwendoline Christie. “I didn’t understand why the women had to be submissive. They predominantly seemed to be of one type—they were often beautiful, but I didn’t understand the relationship between virgin or whore, mother or sex object.” Read our interview with the Game of Thrones star online and in print now | Photo by @jasonbellphoto for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Brienne of Tarth (1/2): Gwendoline Christie poses at the @omearalondon on June 30. We assigned Jason Bell to photograph the Game of Thrones star, who plays the dutiful and fearless warrior Brienne of Tarth. Read our interview with her online now | Photo by @jasonbellphoto for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Painting With Clenched Fist (2/2): Faith Ringgold poses outside her studio in Englewood, New Jersey on June 27. We commissioned Gioncarlo Valentine to photograph Ringgold, who painted posters for the Committee to Defend the Black Panthers in 1970 | Photo by @gioncarlovalentine for Newsweek

Painting With Clenched Fist (1/2): Faith Ringgold stands outside her studio in Englewood, New Jersey on June 27. We commissioned Gioncarlo Valentine to photograph Ringgold, whose work will be on display at the Tate Modern. Opening on July 12, the new exhibition "Soul of a Nation: Art in the Age of Black Power" contains more than 150 works by over 50 artists and chronicles the hope, violence and despair of the years, roughly, between the age of Kennedy and the age of Reagan | Photo by @gioncarlovalentine for Newsweek

Starvation Nation (5/5): The cattle camp near Mingkaman, South Sudan; cattle are central to the country’s culture and economy. South Sudan has all the ingredients to succeed: an optimistic and youthful population, bountiful oil reserves and billions in foreign aid from the U.S. But things fell apart in December 2013 after a squabble between President Salva Kiir and his then-deputy, Riek Machar, escalated into an all-out ethnic conflict that has led to mass rape, cannibalism and thousands of deaths | Photo by @fabio_bucciarelli

Starvation Nation (4/5): A man suffering from cholera is taken by ambulance to a hospital in Mingkaman, South Sudan, on April 26. Since the cholera outbreak began in June 2016, more than 11,000 cases have been reported in the country | Photo by @fabio_bucciarelli

Starvation Nation (3/5): Relatives carry a Dinka woman suffering from cholera to a specialized medical facility in Mingkaman, South Sudan, on April 26. The world’s youngest country faces the simultaneous scourges of civil war, famine and a cholera outbreak | Photo by @fabio_bucciarelli

Starvation Nation (2/5): Adut Dut, who suffers from malnutrition, sits on his brother's lap at the stabilization unit of a hospital in Tonj, South Sudan, on May 6. When his father brought him here in April, Adut was 28 months old and weighed 10 pounds, around a third of the weight of a healthy American male baby | Photo by @fabio_bucciarelli

Starvation Nation (1/5): A man rests in front of a facility for people with disabilities and dermatological diseases near Tonj, South Sudan on May 7. The families living in this area are in situations of extreme poverty and malnutrition, worsened by insufficient humanitarian aid. Just six years after its creation, South Sudan is on the brink of destruction because of a devastating famine sparked by the country's civil war | Photo by @fabio_bucciarelli

Iraqi Christians (5/5): Iraqi Christians displaced by ISIS militants in 2014 walk past a barber shop as a man gets a shave, inside an IDP camp in Erbil. “The future in Iraq is full of ambiguity,” says Sabah Petrus Shema, an Iraqi Christian who now lives in a refugee camp. “After ISIS is gone, there may be another group that is even worse” | Photo by @tommy.trenchard

Iraqi Christians (4/5): Christian children play on a trailer in Ashti IDP camp, near the Kurdish city of Erbil. Most Iraqi Christians are now living in displacement camps in Iraq’s semiautonomous Kurdish region. The conditions are cramped but adequate, in part because the plight of Iraq’s Christians has become a cause for faith-based charities across the world | Photo by @aurelie_dunienville

Iraqi Christians (3/5): A bullet-riddled mannequin stands outside the Immaculate Cathedral in Qaraqosh which was ransacked by ISIS and used for target practice. The destruction of Qaraqosh was systematic, and everywhere you look, the buildings are charred from flames. ISIS fighters went from home to home, dousing them in chemicals and setting them ablaze. In churches, they smashed religious icons and slashed the faces of paintings of Jesus and Mary. Throughout the town, they left booby traps and improvised explosive devices, some of which remain | Photo by @aurelie_dunienville

Iraqi Christians (2/5): Hazim Aboush stands on his rooftop in Qaraqosh from where he watched his farm burn before his escape from ISIS in August 2014. His is one of just a handful of families who recently moved back to the city, months after its liberation by Iraqi forces in October 2016. Though a few Qaraqosh residents have started trickling back in recent months, the vast majority haven’t. Before the ISIS invasion, 50,000 people lived here. Now, there are only an estimated 180 families. The Christians are concerned over how readily some of their Muslim neighbors accepted the rise of ISIS | Photo by @aurelie_dunienville

Iraqi Christians (1/5): A picture of Jesus defaced by Islamic State militants lies on the floor of a church in Qaraqosh, the largest predominantly Christian city in Iraq. During its two-year occupation, the group tried to erase all symbols of Christianity. Though ISIS is almost defeated in Iraq, many Iraqi Christians are afraid to return home, fearing the group may rise again | Photo by @aurelie_dunienville

DJ Khaled (2/2): @djkhaled and son Asahd, photographed May 25 at his home in Beverly Hills. Read our exclusive interview with him online now | Photo by @elizabethrweinberg for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

DJ Khaled (1/2): DJ Khaled: “I don't get into politics, because I don't know nothing about it, and I don't want to know nothing about it.” We assigned Elizabeth Weinberg to photograph @djkhaled for an exclusive interview about his new album "Grateful", conquering Snapchat and his dreams of movie stardom. Read it online now | Photo by @elizabethrweinberg for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Recipe for Success (4/4): Patrons dine at the new Nobu Downtown in New York. The restaurant's original Tribeca location opened in 1994 and closed in March. Its closure marked a kind of end for a restaurant that transformed fine dining in the 1990s. “Luxury dining was all about tablecloths and two and a half hours," architect David Rockwell says. "Nobu’s luxury dining was about scorched-ash tables, an hour-and-a-half dinner, and you get the other hour back to do what you want. There was a redefinition of luxury.” | Photo by @ryanchristopherjones for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Recipe for Success (3/4): Nobu is a household name, and the Rockwell Group is a 250-strong architecture and design firm known for its global work with W hotels, the Hyatt’s Andaz properties and co-working space Neuehouse in Los Angeles and New York. But with its grand design, Nobu Downtown has an ego that its architect, David Rockwell, and its chef, Nobu Matsuhisa, seem to lack | Photo by @ryanchristopherjones for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Recipe for Success (2/4): At the new Nobu Downtown, marble Doric columns draw the eye up, 30 feet, to the ceiling of the lounge area. A black-ash wood sculpture hangs above the backlit onyx bar | Photo by @ryanchristopherjones for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Recipe for Success (1/4): Chef Nobu Matsuhisa and architect David Rockwell at the newly opened Nobu restaurant in New York’s financial district. This grand space is the latest product of a creative relationship between Rockwell, who was brought up in Guadalajara, Mexico, and the Japanese-born Matsuhisa that has spanned two decades and produced 22 restaurants in far-flung spots from Doha, Qatar, and Melbourne, Australia, to Hong Kong and Dallas | Photo by @ryanchristopherjones for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Rural Dementia (5/5): Dave Aman and his wife June embrace in their home in Ontario, New York. Soon, Dave will probably forget who June is. Already, he is incontinent, unable to dress himself and occasionally verbally abusive. They had just sold their farm and begun enjoying their retirement when Dave’s symptoms began. “I get angry with God,” June says | Photo by @dedecim for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Rural Dementia (4/5): Dave and June Aman's house help works on a puzzle in their home in Ontario, New York. Dementia also takes a bitter toll on caregivers. Up to 40 percent of them suffer from depression, which is far higher than the general population in the same age group | Photo by @dedecim for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Rural Dementia (3/5): A cognitive assessment test in one of the offices in the Memory Care facility at the University of Rochester's Medical Center. Neurologists use cognitive tests and scans to spot the early signs of Alzheimer’s, but it is common for a patient to dispute the diagnosis | Photo by @dedecim for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Rural Dementia (2/5): Dave Aman in his home in Ontario, New York on February 23. Three years ago, Dave was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. His worsening condition has made him unable to take care of himself | Photo by @dedecim for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Rural Dementia (1/5): Farm land in Ontario, New York, where June and Dave Aman live. Rural towns have higher numbers of older Americans with dementia, but these counties don't have the resources to help them | Photo by @dedecim for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Prom Night in Gangsterland (7/7): Lauren-Lee Scheepers dances at Phoenix High School's prom night in Manenberg, South Africa. The evening is a welcome moment of hope and dignity for young residents in the violent township | Photo by @ilvynjio

Prom Night in Gangsterland (6/7): Riyaad Grever gets ready for prom in his grandmother's home in Manenberg, South Africa. His family has a hard time making ends meet. There isn't always enough money for food and clothes, but Grever rented a tuxedo for the occasion | Photo by @ilvynjio

Prom Night in Gangsterland (5/7): Lauren-Lee Scheepers gets ready for prom in the family home, where she stays together with her grandmother, mother, aunt, daughter and niece in Manenberg, South Africa | Photo by @ilvynjio

Prom Night in Gangsterland (4/7): Riyaad Grever in the backyard of his grandmother's home in Manenberg, South Africa. He barely knows his father, who is in prison, and his mother died of cancer when he was 12. Grever was running with a gang until his grandmother persuaded him to finish high school. “It’s kwaai, cool, to be a gangster,” he says. “They’ve got the money, cars and girls. There are no jobs here. Joining a gang is the only way to survive.” | Photo by @ilvynjio

Prom Night in Gangsterland (3/7): Lauren-Lee Scheepers sits in a classroom at Phoenix High School in Manenberg, South Africa, waiting for prom invitations to be handed out. Scheepers is a teenage mom and the daughter of a murdered gangbanger. She wants to graduate so she can go on studying to be a police officer, or go into the army | Photo by @ilvynjio

Prom Night in Gangsterland (2/7): Members of the Anti-Gang Unit search boys for drugs and weapons in Manenberg, where jobs are scarce for young people and gangs are a tempting alternative to finishing high school. In 2015 to 2016, in the township of just 60,000 people, there were 60 murders (three times the national average), 130 attempted murders and 2,508 drug-related crimes, making it one of the top 10 worst precincts in South Africa for drug crime, according to police | Photo by @ilvynjio

Prom Night in Gangsterland (1/7): Lauren-Lee Scheepers and her prom date are cheered by neighbors who have come to see her in her prom gown. In Manenberg, South Africa, families that can barely afford food save for prom gowns, tuxedos and limousines. For many of them, it's the first time a family member has finished high school | Photo by @ilvynjio

Medical Training (5/5): Priest Igor rings the bells before the medical train's chapel service starts on November 11, 2016. The train only comes about once a year to each town on its route | Photo by Emile Ducke

Medical Training (4/5): The medical train is named after Saint Lukas, a priest and doctor who served during World War II. The train carries its own chapel car in his honor, where patients can visit before and after their treatments | Photo by Emile Ducke

Medical Training (3/5): Elena Semina from the town of Kuragino, Russia waits for her EEG examination to begin on November 10, 2016. She traveled to the small village of Tuba, where the medical train stops before reaching Kuragino, in order to circumvent the rush demand in her town. The train has its own laboratory and pharmacy, and the standard battery of equipment to conduct diagnostic tests | Photo by Emile Ducke

Medical Training (2/5): Patients register at the reception in the beginning of the train where they will be given appointment times with doctors in Son, Russia, on November 6, 2016. The treatments are free of charge. The train's duration of stay is dependent on the size of the village—the train only stopped for one day in Son, which has 740 inhabitants | Photo by Emile Ducke

Medical Training (1/5): Patients wait for their medical treatment and laboratory results in the narrow gangways of the Saint Lukas medical train in Kuragino, Russia, on November 13, 2016. The government-sponsored train is one of five providing basic health care to underserved remote towns in central and eastern Russia | Photo by Emile Ducke

Fractured Syria Lost (15/27): Jabez' friend had gone to their home and reported that their home had been completely stripped after a recent bombing. "I am from Syria. I live in Jordan. I only wish to return to my home country, Syria. I mean its streets. I wish I could see my neighbors, family, loved ones, friends. I miss its air, water. Everything in it." | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

Fractured Syria Lost (14/27): Jabez’ keeps a picture of their street in Homs, taken the week before they left. His sister had recently gone back to Syria but he hadn’t heard from her again | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

Fractured Syria Lost (13/27): “Jabez” and his family left Homs in March of 2013. For nearly fifteen years his parents had worked to buy the corner grocery and coffee shop and the home their family lived in. They made the final payments right before they had to flee | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

One year before this photograph was taken, Marie—not her real name—was raped a gunpoint by a man she thought wanted to help her. Marie was a student looking for a job in Port-au-Prince, Haiti’s capital. “I met this guy on the street,” she says. “We started to chat. He said that one of his friends was looking for someone like me. He said that he needed to go to his place. When we got there, he pulled out his gun. This is when it happened.”Marie’s experience is all too common in Haiti. During the military’s rule from 1991 to 1994, it used rape as a weapon to intimidate and punish women, and after a coup in 2004, thousands of women and children were sexually assaulted, including more than a hundred victims who alleged assault by U.N. peacekeepers, according to recent investigations. Women’s organizations have pushed for reforms to the penal code to improve legislation protecting women, though government inaction and political instability have stalled the attempts. Rape became a serious crime only in 2005, after a group of women pushed for a change in the law. Previously, a rapist could pay off or marry his victim | Photo by @benedicte_kurzen

Long View: Rising sea temperatures have triggered a massive dying off of the Great Barrier Reef, and researchers warn it may never recover with more damage to come.

Once rich with coral and sea life, 90 percent of the Great Barrier Reef today is composed of large swafts of bleached white or dead coral. Warm seas off the coast of Queensland, Australia, killed some two-thirds of a nearly 500-mile stretch of coral in 2016 after warm water caused the coral to expel living algae, triggering it to calcify or turn white, a process known as bleaching. Researchers have called it the worst die-off of coral ever recorded at the reef.

Even the areas that survived will not recover to full health, scientists from the ARC Centre of Excellence for Integrated Coral Reef Studies said in a report, as unseasonable hot water becomes more frequent, causing more bleaching. The reef has experienced three bleaching events in the last 20 years—in 1998, 2002 and 2016, with another event expected this year. Two consecutive years of bleaching would be unprecedented and may alter the region for generations.

Earth Day (5/5): “In my practice it’s all I’m doing these days: battling pseudoscience. I spend a lot of time unteaching things people have learned from Dr. Oz,” said Tamara Freuman, 41, a registered dietician from Nyack, New York | Photo by @jessfirger #AssignmentNewsweek

Earth Day (4/5): “The Trump administration is destroying our scientific data. Not to mention, he has tiny hands,” said Melissa O’Brien, 56, a computer programmer from Jersey City, New Jersey | Photo by @jessfirger #AssignmentNewsweek

Earth Day (3/5): “These people have a veneer on the march for it being pro-science. We all know it’s a way of saying ‘we hate Trump.’ Most of America appreciates the fact that he’s standing up to North Korea and the Middle East,” said Jim Macdonald, 67, of Flushing, Queens, NYC | Photo by @jessfirger #AssignmentNewsweek

Earth Day (2/5): “Evolution is obviously the most radical scientific theory of all them. It means there was nobody telling the universe what to do,” said Perry Hoberman, 62, a media artist and professor from Los Angeles | Photo by @jessfirger #AssignmentNewsweek

Earth Day (1/5): On Saturday, millions of people worldwide took to the streets for the March for Science. Organizers in Washington, D.C. reported more than 600 satellite marches worldwide planned for the day. The mass demonstrations, held on Earth Day, were meant to raise awareness about the importance of funding (and trusting) science. New York City's march drew throngs of geeks with both a personal and professional passion for evidence-based research, many with a knack for pro-science messaging. Newsweek's @jessfirger took to the streets of NYC to find out what people are saying. #AssignmentNewsweek

Radical Therapy (3/5): Trauma survivors often suffer from something called "dissociation"--they become numb to their emotions. In CRM, the emphasis is on making sure the emotions from old memories can be revisited and dissolved safely | Photo by @lademiddel #AssignmentNewsweek

Radical Therapy (2/5): CRM was developed over the past decade by Lisa Schwarz, a licensed psychologist in Pennsylvania who has practiced for 30 years. Schwarz has taught the technique to more than 1,500 therapists around the world | Photo by @lademiddel #AssignmentNewsweek

Radical Therapy (1/5): Some suffering from post-traumatic stress disorder report physical reactions such as loss of muscle control, a freezing sensation, bouts of nausea or panic attacks that feel like a giant screw turning in the gut. The Comprehensive Resource Model (CRM) is a new and relatively obscure method of trauma therapy that fuses elements of psychology, spirituality, neurobiology and shamanic "power animals." We assigned Cristina de Middel to photograph a conceptual interpretation of Matthew Green's story about CRM. See it on newsstands this week | Photo by @lademiddel #AssignmentNewsweek
Fractured Syria Lost (12/27): "K" would prefer to go back to Syria if only it were safe, writing, "I would like to return to Syria. My name is K. I am 15 years old" | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

Fractured Syria Lost (4/11): Though it was only opened in 2012 as temporary housing, the UNHCR/Jordanian camp is now Jordan's fourth largest city, causing myriad infrastructure issues | Photo by @alexjohnbeck
Fractured Syria Lost (10/27): a view along one of the main roads of Zaatari camp | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

Long view: As the war in Yemen enters its third year, about 100 civilians per month are dying from the Saudi-led coalition's air strikes, according to the United Nations human rights office. Yemenis struggle through a mounting food crisis, infrastructural collapse and a lack of access to medical care as blockades cut off humanitarian aid and trucks carrying vital resources, while falling bombs pummel the buildings and bodies around them.

At an orphanage in Sanaa, Yemen's capital, children dream only of normalcy. The al-Shawkani Foundation for Orphan Care is located just 100 yards from al-Nahdain mountain, widely believed to be arms depot that has been repeatedly bombarded by the Saudi-led coalition's fighter jets. Since the peak is stocked with explosives, each strike rattles the whole city and sends huge mushroom clouds into the skies.

Radical Therapy (5/5): CRM practitioners claim the breathing exercises visualizations and other tools can help cleanse toxic emotions from the "emotional brain" while activating neural pathways associated with being cared for and nurtured. Girded with their "power animals" and other resources, survivors can finally release feelings that would have otherwise been too much to face. | Photo by @lademiddel

Radical Therapy (4/5): Nobody can say for sure precisely how psychological trauma might damage structures in the brain. One hypothesis is that the brain releases such a deluge of stress chemicals when it perceives it is facing imminent death that certain brain cells die, causing a "blown fuse" effect that leads to chronic malfunction. | Photo by @lademiddel for Newsweek #AssignmentNewsweek

Fractured Syria Lost (9/27): Noor keeps a picture sent by her 24-year-old son, Ghofran, on his arrival in Germany. He was working in a bakery when this picture was taken. "I didn't hear from him for a week when he was on his way to Germany. A week. It is bittersweet because he's far away, but he's safe." | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

Fractured Syria Lost (8/27): Noor arrived at the Zaatari Refugee Camp in northern Jordan. "We want peace in our country," she says. "When will my children, sisters and I live in peace in our country, Syria?" | Photo by @alexjohnbeck
Fractured Syria Lost (7/27): The Zaatari Refugee Camp in Jordan | Photo by @alexjohnbeck
Fractured Syria Lost (6/27): Looking toward Syria from the Beqaa Valley, Lebanon | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

Fractured Syria Lost (5/27): "Shatilla" carries a picture (previous image) sent by her elder son, who was later killed in shelling in Yarmouk, a Palestinian refugee camp in the suburbs of Damascus. She now lives in a camp in Beirut, Jordan | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

Fractured Syria Lost (4/27): In February, Syrian refugees in Lebanon and Jordan shared pictures and videos they saved after fleeing, in many cases the only reminders of a life uprooted by conflict. More than five million refugees have fled Syria since war broke out in 2011, and more than 1.6 million of them reside in those two countries alone | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

Fractured Syria Lost (3/27): A bus waiting for more passengers on one of the outer roads of Zaatari. Camps often operate in essence like towns, which means people often find a need to travel, either to visit relatives or for other reasons. This bus was making its way out of Zaatari just before sunset | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

Fractured Syria Lost (2/27): "I miss my beloved Syria. I miss my family, my brothers and my home. I long to return to my neighborhood, where love, tenderness and understanding exist." She asked that we not use her real name, out of fear for her family. After years of civil war in Syria, neighboring Lebanon now faces an unprecedented refugee crisis, with one in four people now a refugee of the conflict | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

Fractured Syria Lost (1/27): By some estimates, about 1.3 trillion photos will be snapped on cellphones across the world this year alone. That would be an average of about 176 photos a person per day if everyone owned a cellphone. But say a catastrophic event interrupted your life, such as a violent conflict forcing you from your home: If you could only save certain photos, which would you choose, and which one is the closest to your heart? | Photo by @alexjohnbeck

World View (8/8): Two models backstage during an Africa Fashion Week in Lagos, Nigeria. Yagazie Emezi has described her work as driven by discovery for an Africa she wasn't familiar with and "a passion for the preservation of the African aesthetic." Emezi attended school in New Mexico before returning to work as a documentary photojournalist in Aba, Nigeria | Photo by @yagazieemezi

World View (7/8): Colombian self-taught photojournalist Juanita Escobar has always been interested in the relationship between humans and the environments that surround them. For her project Llano, she shadowed the llanero, rural herders who drive cattle every summer. The llanero were originally part Spanish and Indian and have a strong culture, including a distinctive form of music | Photo by @juanitafotografa

Long View: Though he's not yet a Canadian citizen, Arun Daniel is already playing like one. The 11-year-old refugee from Sri Lanka arrived in Canada just two weeks before taking a crash course in one of the country's favorite winter sports. 
He'd seen curling on television before, but hadn't thought of it as a real sport. "It looked like not that fun. I was like, 'Why is it taking such a long time?' It felt like hockey is better," he told Reuters. "But when I came and really did it, I felt like, 'Oh, I shouldn't say that'." Arun is one of 45 resettled refugees from Afghanistan, Syria, Kurdistan and other nations who spent Wednesday throwing stones, sweeping, wiping out on the rink and laughing at the Royal Canadian Curling Club in Toronto. Organized by the Together Project, a nonprofit that aims to provide social support to government-sponsored refugees, the day-long event paired the newcomers with volunteer teachers. It was the latest in a series of cultural outings arranged by the group that have included maple syrup tastings and visits to the Royal Ontario Museum. 
Government-sponsored refugees are more likely to face unemployment and other integration challenges than those who are privately sponsored, according a a report by Canada's immigration department. Though settlement agencies help these newcomers with practical concerns, the Together Project helps to fill a need to prevent marginalization and social isolation and help with the cultural adjustment. "Curling is a fantastic, very Canadian winter sport, and we thought that they might be interested in learning about winter sports in Canada since we have quite a long winter here," the project's co-founder, Anna Hill, told Reuters.

This week in #BigShots we circle the globe with stories from London, South Korea, Guatemala and Kenya. Londoners assist the injured after an assailant drove a car through people on Westminster Bridge before crashing into the railings near Britain's Houses of Parliament on March 22. The attacker then got out the car and ran into the parliamentary complex, fatally stabbing a police officer before police shot and killed him. Four people died, including the attacker, and at least 20 more were injured. The suspect was later identified as 52-year-old British-born Khalid Masood. || In Jindo, South Korea, workers try to raise the sunken Sewol ferry between two barges during a salvage operation on March 23. The 6,800-ton ferry emerged from the water nearly three years after it capsized and sank into violent seas off the country's southwestern coast, in an emotional moment for a country that continues to search for closure to one of its deadliest ever disasters. || Members of the Barrio 18 gang who allegedly participated in a prison riot are escorted in handcuffs to court in Guatemala City on March 21. The nation's security forces rescued four guards whom gang members held as hostages after the riot that began on March 19 at a juvenile correctional facility. The inmates set mattresses on fire and tried to escape the complex, killing several guards and injuring others, authorities said. || A devastating drought in Kenya is bringing about new dangers from disease thriving among livestock which has starved to death in the region's worst drought in five years. A boy carries a carcass of a goat on March 21 to burn hoping to head off spread of disease. For the nomadic communities in the area, they store their savings in animals rather than banks and each carcass is a major loss. || Photos by Toby Melville, Choi Young-Su, Moises Castillo and Goran Tomasevic
World View (6/8): Emilia Lloret is a Quito-based photojournalist who has been documenting the Tsáchila Aguavil family, member of the Native American culture, the Tsáchilas | Photo by @emilialloret

World View (5/8): Chilean photojournalist Tamara Merino focuses her independent projects on native communities in Brazil, Mexico, Cuba and Australia. Merino’s project “Underland” documents a town called Coober Pedy in the middle of the Australian outback that’s home to 47 different nationalities of immigrants, ex-prisoners, and veterans of World War II who have decided to escape their past lives and take refuge in this remote and unique place | Photo by @tamaramerino_photography

World View (4/8): Caskets are carried on the way to the cemetery to bury the 77 victims of the Covadonga massacre, in Estrella Polar, Chajul. Guatemala-based Daniele Volpe has covered the deaths of victims of violence and human rights violations across the country | Photo by @daniele_volpe

World View (3/8): Somali-American filmmaker and @EverydayAfrica contributor Idil Ibrahim photographs girls playing in a rural village an hour from Kabwe, Zambia, where many locals are subsistence farmers who grow tomatoes, cabbage, kale and other staples | Photo by @I_AM_IDIL

This week in #BigShots we circle the globe with stories from Iraq, Jerusalem, Japan and California. 
Iraqi federal police officers access the damage after a suicide bomber from the Islamic State militant group attacked them with a bulldozer in this city on March 15, killing four people and injuring 12. Already in control of the eastern half of the city, Iraqi forces are making their way west through the Old City, home of Mosul’s al-Nuri mosque, where three years ago ISIS announced its caliphate. A black ISIS flag still hangs from one of the mosque’s minarets, but it may not be there for long. || An Ultra-Orthodox Jewish man gets hit by a police water canon during a protest against Israeli army conscription, on March. 15. The Ultra-Orthodox have for years been exempt from military service, which is compulsory for Jewish Israelis. The arrangement has caused widespread resentment among Israel's secular majority. The ultra-Orthodox claim the military will expose their youth to secularism and undermine their devout lifestyle. || In Japan, elementary school students crouch during an emergency drill in northern Japan on March 17. It was the first time the Japanese government has held such exercises, which are designed to simulate the reaction to a North Korean ballistic missile attack. The drills coincided with a visit to the region by U.S. Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, who said that America’s policy of “strategic patience” with North Korea had ended and that all options are on the table to halt Pyongyang’s nuclear weapons program. || And in California the wildflowers were back in bloom after nearly five years of drought. Five-year-olds Julia Lu, left, and Amy Liu walk through a massive spring wildflower bloom caused by a wet winter, on March 14. Southern California's deserts and hillsides are ablaze with color after a wet winter spurred what scientists say is the biggest wildflower bloom in years. || Photos by Laurent Van Der Stockt, Oded Balilty, Jun Hirata and Lucy Nicholson

World View (2/8): The WPP statistics reveal that the vast majority of news images are produced by Western-born men. This is the dominant point of view through which the entire world continues to see and understand itself. In Andrew Esiebo's image of two women with their cell phones in Lagos, Nigeria, Esiebo presents a less cliched approach to story of Africa. He says has focused his work on chronicling the rapid development of urban Nigeria, something seldom explored | Photo by @andrewesiebo

World View (1/8): Inequities among photojournalists produce a familiar image. Lauded photojournalism organization World Press Photo (WPP) released its second “State of News Photography” report in November 2016, a document that addressed many key issues affecting contemporary photojournalists. Most striking was the fact that of the nearly 2,000 news photographers surveyed internationally, a mere 15 percent were female. Also concerning was the revelation that 65 percent were from Western nations, specifically Europe, the United States and Australia. Brazilian photojournalist such as Joao Castellano are rare; here he captures a boy eating ice cream at Piscinao de Ramos or Big Pool of Ramos, an artificial beach in the heart of Favela de Mare, in northern Rio de Janeiro | Photo by @joaocastellano

This week in #BigShots we circle the globe with stories from France, Syria, Iraq and the West Bank. Fighting to retake Mosul from the Islamic State militant group continues with American-backed collation forces checking people door to door as they attempt to root out insurgents who have set car bombs, used suicide bombers, snipers and weapons filled with toxic chemicals in recent weeks. On March 4 an Iraqi soldier inspects two men for weapons and explosives. In Syria, a man waters herbs on his roof in the rebel-held town of Arbin on March 3. || It’s been six years since Syria’s civil war began—a conflict that started as a series of nonviolent protests but quickly morphed into an international crisis that’s killed hundreds of thousands and left much of the country in ruins. Recently, Amnesty International reported that forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad hung thousands of people after a series of quick sham trials. || In France, Marine Le Pen, the head of the far-right National Front party and a leading candidate in this year’s presidential election, holds a rally on February 26. Some have compared her to Donald Trump because of her populist stances on immigration and globalization and polls suggest her message is resonating with voters. Current President François Hollande, in a rarely candid statement, has said his “ultimate duty” is to make sure she doesn’t win. || And in the West Bank, border police grapple with hundreds of protesters on February 28 during a court ordered demolition of eight homes in a Jewish settlement which had been built on Palestinian land. This protest remained relatively civil, unlike a similar stand off weeks before which turned violent near Ramallah, as settlers threw rocks and set fires to stop Israeli security forces. | Photos by Goran Tomasevic, Amer Almohibany, Jeff J Mitchell and Ronen Zvulun

Cuban Faith (9/9): Muhammad Ali walks home under the Capitolio building, in the Habana Vieja quarter of La Habana. Ali, born Manuel, became Muslim 20 years ago, at a time when very few Cubans had had any exposure to the religion | Photo by  Joan Alvado

Cuban Faith (8/9): Rolando Tamayo, 30, rests at home with his daughter. Rolando, who goes by Mustafa in Muslim environments, converted to Islam in 2012, and now is the Imam of the Cuban province of Sancti Spiritus | Photo by Joan Alvado

Cuban Faith (7/9): Muslims gather in a new mosque in La Habana. The mosque, which opened in June of 2015, was built by the Arabia Saudi authorities in the Habana Vieja quarter, with the approval of the Cuban government | Photo by  Joan Alvado

Cuban Faith (6/9): Abu Duyanah Ali gives his wife a ride to work in the Playa District in downtown La Habana. Ali, born in La Habana, is the founder of the Cuban Association for the Study of Islam, one of the few Islamic groups in the country. Adapting to Islam has been a significant departure for Cubans, many of whom grew up eating pork and drinking alcohol. Most Cuban Muslims have adapted gradually. A lack of experts or imams to guide their way has meant that old traditions survive even as the converts adopt new ways of living under Islam | Photo by  Joan Alvado

Cuban Faith (5/9): Rosalba Lamanier joins her friend, Danay, and Danay's son, in the Mosque of La Habana. In the early 1990s, the handful of Muslim citizens in Cuba faced possible persecution by the regime for practicing their religion, but most worshipped on their own; few could teach them about their newfound faith. Now they have leadership, teachers and a large house of worship that opened in Havana in June 2015. The mosque distributes traditional Muslim dress to men and women and donates lamb to congregants during Ramadan | Photo by  Joan Alvado

Cuban Faith (4/9): Juan Enriquez, 70, became known by his Muslim name, Yahya, after he converted to Islam in 2007. Here, he calls to Friday's prayer in the mosque of Camagüey, which was built inside a private home to avoid problems with the Cuban authorities. Despite being part of the fastest-growing religious group in the world—a Pew Research Center report estimates the world’s Muslim population will increase by 73 percent by 2050—Cuba’s Muslims can seem invisible, even to other Cubans. “No one in Havana, even my Cuban friends, knew that there were Muslims,” says photojournalist Joan Alvado | Photo by  Joan Alvado

Cuban Faith (3/9): Ahmed Agüero, a Muslim originally from Camagüey, Cuba’s third largest city, stops by the Malecón of La Habana, a 5-mile-long seawall, where he runs every morning. Because there isn’t a long legacy of Islam in Cuba, many of the island’s Muslims are converts who found the faith after speaking with students and diplomats visiting from Muslim-majority countries | Photo by Joan Alvado

Cuban Faith (2/9): Under portraits of Che Guevara and Fidel Castro, Muhammad Ali waits with his grandson Dario for jujitsu classes in a gym in historic Old Havana, one of the densest parts of the city. The religion is now quietly growing in Cuba, where there are as many as 9,000 Muslims. While they represent a tiny segment of Cuba’s 11.3 million population, it’s a significant increase from roughly a dozen in the early 1990s. “The Communist Party has been making decisions to open up religious plurality,” says Michael Leo Owens, associate professor of political science at Emory University in Atlanta. “Islam will naturally grow” | Photo by  Joan Alvado

Cuban Faith (1/9): Yarima plays with Islamic prayer beads as her father, Ali, 33, holds her. Ali and his wife converted to Islam in 2014; Yarima is one of the first babies in Cuba born a Muslim. The first time a pope ever set foot in Cuba was in 1998, when John Paul II traveled to the Communist state. The visit was the result of a thaw between the Vatican and Cuba’s president, Fidel Castro, who banned religion in 1959 when he seized power. Cuba’s majority-Catholic population welcomed the pontiff with great excitement; several hundred thousand people, including Castro, attended the Mass led by the pope in Havana. Meanwhile, a small number of other Cubans drew their own conclusion from the regime’s growing tolerance of religion: Perhaps soon the state would increasingly accept Islam too | Photo by  Joan Alvado
Warriors (8/8): Nastya and her 7-year-old daughter in their kitchen in Kiev. Nastya regularly heads to the front line of combat, leaving behind her two children | Photo by @sarahblesener
Warriors (7/8): Natalya, who works as a nurse for the Right Sector, unpacks her bag after moving into a new position | Photo by @sarahblesener
Warriors (6/8): Nika, 24, a sniper for the Ukrainian army, on the Bakhmut front lines in eastern Ukraine | Photo by @sarahblesener
Warriors (5/8): A nurse from the Right Sector in her room at the Ukrainian army base on the front lines of Bakhmut | Photo by @sarahblesener

Warriors (4/8): Soldiers from the Right Sector take a break at a base near the front lines of Debaltseve in the Donbass region. The far-right nationalist group is now part of the 54th Brigade, which belongs to the Ukrainian army | Photo by @sarahblesener

Warriors (3/8): Natalya, a member of the Right Sector group, holds hands with her husband, Vlad. Natalya and Vlad met at the start of the revolution and were married a year later. Together, they are stationed on the front lines in the city of Bakhmut | Photo by @sarahblesener

Warriors (2/8): Two officers of the Ukrainian armed forces walk through the corridor of a shelled-out school in the village of Shyrokyne in Mariupol. In September, American photographer Sarah Blesener spent two weeks embedded with the Right Sector and other Ukrainian troops. “The first thing I noticed was how many girls and young women were there,” she says. “They all do the same things as the men, and they all seemed incredibly brave” | Photo by @sarahblesener

Warriors (1/8): Mariana, 29, is a member of the border patrol in Mariupol, eastern Ukraine. She has been in the army for five years and has been stationed on the front lines of the war for more than six months. Almost three years later, Ukrainian are still fighting in a war that has led to the deaths of more than 9,000 people, including civilians, Ukrainian troops, separatists, Russian servicemen and members of pro-Kiev militias. Pounded by daily shelling, many towns near the front lines are now practically empty. Mariana is one of many woman serving on the front lines | Photo by @sarahblesener

In his first week in office, Trump would sign a slew of executive actions relating to immigration, government hiring, the environment and abortion, while also halting investigations into voter intimidation and policing of minority communities | Photo by J. Scott Applewhite/Getty

Inaugurations (20/21): President Barack Obama and First Lady Michelle Obama sing together as they dance during the Inaugural Ball on January 21, 2013. Obama was sworn in for his second term of office earlier that day | Photo by Chip Somodevilla/Getty

Inaugurations (19/21): President George W. Bush sits at his desk in the Oval Office for the first time on Inaugural Day on January 20, 2001, as his father, former President George H.W. Bush looks on | Photo by Eric Draper/White House/Reuters

Inaugurations (17/21): President-elect George H. W. Bush shows off his new inaugural limo license plate with his inaugural co-chairpersons Robert Holt, right, and Renne Percy Korth on December 1, 1988 | Photo by Terry Ashe/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty
Inaugurations (16/21): President-elect Ronald Reagan sits at desk writing his inaugural speech at home on January 1, 1981 | Photo by Dirck Halstead/The LIFE Images Collection/Getty

Inaugurations (6/21): President Calvin Coolidge takes the oath of office, administered by his father, John, by kerosene light at the Coolidge Homestead on August 3, 1923 in Pymouth, Vermont. Coolidge took office following the death of President Harding the previous evening | Photo by Bettmann/Getty

Inaugurations (1/21): President William McKinley delivers his inaugural address on March 4, 1897 | Photo by Photo12/UIG/Getty
