Election Day 10/10: 2008: BARACK OBAMA VS. JOHN MCCAIN

History was made when Barack Obama became the first African-American to be elected president of the United States. His running mate, Joe Biden, was also the first Roman Catholic ever elected vice president.

Election Day 9/10: 2000: GEORGE W. BUSH VS. AL GORE

And then there was 2000: The closest, craziest election the U.S. had seen. After a dead-heat election, the results of which hinged on Florida and ended up triggering a mandatory recount and even a Supreme Court case, Florida's votes were awarded to Bush and he won the election.

Election Day 8/10: 1992: BILL CLINTON VS. GEORGE H.W. BUSH VS. ROSS PEROT

Democratic Arkansas Governor Bill Clinton won both the popular and electoral vote in this bizarre election, which put independent businessman Ross Perot in the spotlight. Perot came very close to upsetting the two-party system but blew it when he dropped out of the race to protect his daughter from a "plot" to disrupt her wedding.

Election Day 7/10: 1988: GEORGE H.W. BUSH VS. MICHAEL DUKAKIS

In the 1988 election, George H.W. Bush beat out opponent Michael Dukakis with a substantial margin of the popular vote and the electoral college, one that no candidate to date has matched. This was also the election that delivered one of the best one-two punches in vice presidential debate history when Dan Quayle, Bush’s running mate, compared himself to John F. Kennedy, to which Democratic vice presidential nominee Lloyd Bentsen replied, "Senator, you're no Jack Kennedy."

Election Day 6/10: 1980: RONALD REAGAN VS. JIMMY CARTER VS. JOHN B. ANDERSON

This election marked the beginning of the “Reagan Era,” a return to a conservative approach to politics. The Republican nominee for president won, and the Republicans took back control of the Senate for the first time since 1955.

Election Day 5/10: 1976: JIMMY CARTER VS. GERALD FORD

The 1976 presidential election was an upset. Gerald Ford became the first sitting president to never be elected to national office, after succeeding Nixon in 1974 after the Watergate scandal. The winner, former Georgia Governor Jimmy Carter, ran as a Washington outsider who was relatively unknown.

Election Day 4/10: 1972: RICHARD M. NIXON VS. GEORGE MCGOVERN

Nixon’s popularity won him 60 percent of the popular vote, which was largely due to his promise to terminate American involvement in the Vietnam War. While the election was a win for the Republican nominee, it was a loss for Republicans in the Senate. As reported in Newsweek's November 13, 1972, issue, “The Senate had always been one of the Republicans’ chief targets this year. Yet, as it turned out, the Democrats not only held firm but picked up two seats to expand their margin to 57-43.”

Election Day 3/10: 1968: RICHARD M. NIXON VS. HUBERT HUMPHREY VS. GEORGE WALLACE

This was the election that “restored law and order,” as Nixon put it during his successful campaign. The 1968 election was largely centered on race riots and civil unrest, after the assassination of Martin Luther King Jr. and with increasing disapproval of the Vietnam War. Ironically, this was the first election after the Voting Rights Act of 1965, which prohibited racial discrimination in voting.

Election Day 2/10:  1960: JOHN F. KENNEDY VS. RICHARD M. NIXON

The 1960 election included the first televised presidential debate in history and also marked the first time Alaska and Hawaii voters could participate. It was the closest presidential election since 1916, making Kennedy’s victory a close call by 84 electoral votes.

Election Day 1/10: As Americans head to the polls Tuesday to choose a president, join us as we dive into 60 years of Newsweek to highlight some of the most contentious races in history.  1956: DWIGHT D. EISENHOWER VS. ADLAI E. STEVENSON

The 1956 election was a win for re-elected President Dwight D. Eisenhower and marked the beginning of peace for the American public after the Korean War. Although Eisenhower was popular, the public had questioned if his health made him suitable for another four years in office. It was also expected that women voters, for the first time since they were granted suffrage, would equal, and possibly outnumber, male voters.
How Can I Help You? (7/7):A call center agent sleeps during her break at 1 a.m. After dinner, she has a break of 30 minutes at her desk | Photo by @josesmatos

How Can I Help You? (6/7): Bessie, 32, cares for her niece before work. Bessie is a transgender woman who started working in call centers in 2009. Unlike other businesses in the Philippines, call centers do not discriminate against transgender people | Photo by @josesmatos

How Can I Help You? (5/7): Workers present cakes to celebrate the birthdays of three people about to finish their overnight shift. Once a month in this American-owned company, there is a meeting to celebrate every birthday from that month. | Photo by @josesmatos

How Can I Help You? (4/7): Danil, 19, is Filipino but was born and grew up in Greece. In 2015 he came to the Philippines to work at a call center dealing with Greece customers, earning around $1000 a month | Photo by @josesmatos

How Can I Help You? (3/7): Customer service agents work by email for a North American account for a company competing with Uber on April 14 in Manila, Philippines. As these workers only help customers by email, they don´t need to work at night and can have a normal work schedule, unlike many others doing similar work. The account was recently shut down—a common occurence as clients shuffle business from one company to another in order to lower costs. Although the call center industry helps people in the Philippines economically by increasing their purchasing power, it is not necessarily the most stable of professions. | Photo by @josesmatos

How Can I Help You? (2/7): Christine, 34, dries her hair before going out with friends. Her overnight call center hours make her stay up at night on the weekends. She has worked in this business for the past 11 years. Although she has a university degree in management and business, she started her call center career one month before finishing her studies. She has already worked for seven different companies in the industry. Her wage has changed significantly—she started off earning $250 a month and in April 2016 she was earning around $700. | Photo by @josesmatos

How Can I Help You? (1/7): Michelle, 34, and Ian, 33, work from home while their daughters have breakfast on April 27 in Manila. They work opposite shifts for the same call center, so they don't see each other much, but their schedules enable them to spend more time with their kids. Together they make $1,800 USD a month, which is well above average for a family in the Philippines | Photo by @josesmatos

Drugs and Death (7/7): The coffin of a suspected drug pusher is placed on a tomb as relatives grieve during a burial ceremony in Pasay. The president shows no sign of changing his strategy. In response to criticism, Duterte has said, “We are willing to submit ourselves for an investigation before anybody... But…the fight against drugs will continue unrelenting until we have destroyed the apparatus operating in the entire country.” The message of his speech was clear. The deaths will continue | Photo by @eacayan

Drugs and Death (6/7): Relatives of a suspected drug pusher grieve during his burial ceremony in Pasay on August 3. Despite daily reminders or police killings, the public is largely in favor of the president | Photo by @eacayan

Drugs and Death (5/7): Police and media inspect a Manila crime scene on July 31. Acayan says the streets are quieter as a result of the deaths—young men in particular don’t want to walk around at night, lest they be mistaken for drug dealers. But people’s fear is not a sign of disapproval. Duterte commands a 91 percent trust rating among Filipinos, many of whom want an end to the country’s drug problem, no matter the cost | Photo by @eacayan

Drugs and Death (4/7): Investigators comb through bullet shells scattered around the corpse of a suspected drug runner outside a store after he was shot by unidentified gunmen in Quezon city on August 1. Human rights groups and the Catholic Church have condemned these extra judicial killings, but Duterte just called these groups out on national television and told them, “Don’t fuck with me” | Photo by @eacayan

Drugs and Death (3/7): Relatives weep over the corpse of a suspected drug pusher after he was shot dead following a police operation in Manila on August 3. "I can say the mood right now in the streets is the people are afraid. Especially in the poorer areas," said Acayan. "The people are afraid to commit any more crimes, but also the people are afraid that they might get wrongly accused and killed. Petty crime rate has dropped significantly, but murder otherwise has doubled" | Photo by @eacayan

Drugs and Death (2/7): Relatives of a suspected drug pusher weep after he was shot dead following a police operation in Manila on August 3. When Duterte was announced winner of the presidential race, police started strictly implementing curfews. They began rounding up many suspects believed to be involved with drugs and petty crimes. The first killings came soon after, and the death count quickly escalated. Currently, an average of 11 drug suspects are killed each day | Photo by @eacayan

Drugs and Death (1/7): The corpse of a suspected drug pusher and victim of a vigilante-style execution with his hands tied and head wrapped with tape lies under a bridge in Manila on July 31. At least 700 people suspected to have been involved with drugs have been killed by police or vigilantes in the Philippines since President Rodrigo Duterte came into power more than a month ago. Duterte pledged to kill thousands in an all-out war against drugs, the only real plank in an election platform that won him the presidency by a massive margin in a country where drugs and crime are deeply rooted | Photo by @eacayan

Gitmo (6/6): Al-Merfedy takes a back road to the town square. He prefers to walk away from the curious gaze of locals, who seem unsure of him and other former detainees. “The idea seemed to be to get them out of Guantánamo at almost any cost,” says David Remes, a lawyer to many present and former detainees, including al-Merfedy. “They were dropped into strange lands, with cultures, religions and language far different from their own, and where they were bound to be treated like pariahs.” | Photo by@alexkpotter #AssignmentNewsweek

Gitmo (5/6): Al-Quraishi learned to paint at Guantánamo. It was his outlet, he says. This painting was originally taken away, and he was told, "Never paint anything like this again." He claimed to have had thousands of drawings, but in the end, the US returned to him only a small folder | Photo by@alexkpotter #AssignmentNewsweek

Gitmo (4/6): Sabry al-Quraishi, another released detainee, lives a lonely life in Semey. "I miss my family—I was in prison for over a decade, and I am still not able to bring my family here to visit me," he says | Photo by@alexkpotter #AssignmentNewsweek

Gitmo (3/6): In Zvolen al-Merfedy keeps to himself, saying he feels isolated from society, as if he's traded one prison for another. His bird, which a psychologist gave him, is sometimes the interaction he has on any given day. "After I have been in a cage my whole life, I hate seeing anything in a cage," he says | Photo by@alexkpotter #AssignmentNewsweek

Gitmo (2/6): Al-Merfedy's room is spartan. His bed, computer and a map of Zvolen are the core of his apartment. "My life is at this desk," he says. Over the past two years, the Obama administration has renewed its push to close Gitmo and release detainees it no longer deems a threat. Of the roughly 780 original prisoners, 61 remain behind bars, 20 of whom are cleared for release. But detainees from war-torn countries like Yemen, Libya and Syria cannot return home; the U.S. government fears they might join or rejoin extremist groups | Photo by@alexkpotter #AssignmentNewsweek.

Gitmo (1/6): Two years ago, Hussein al-Merfedy was one of dozens of detainees the U.S. kept locked up at Gitmo, even though they were never charged with a crime. Though he had been cleared for release in 2008, he spent more than a decade in prison without explanation. That changed on November 14, 2014, when the military handcuffed and blindfolded al-Merfedy and put him on a plane. When he landed, however, he was not home in Yemen; he was thousands of miles away in Slovakia, a stranger in a new country | Photo by@alexkpotter #AssignmentNewsweek

9/11 (6/6): John Soltes, a retired cop for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which had oversight of the World Trade Center towers, is under treatment for "the World Trade Center cough.” He worked at Ground Zero for almost nine months clearing debris and recovering the remains of his colleagues. “I only had the cough for a year,” he says. “I know some guys who still have it.” His cough led to GERD and a serious complication of that condition, called Barrett’s esophagus, which can develop into cancer. “I’ve already dealt with skin cancer on my face, my cheek and my back,” which are also 9/11-related, he says. “So I am trying to be careful” | Photo by@dedecim #AssignmentNewsweek

9/11 (5/6): Paul Gerasimczyk, 57, is a retired NYPD police officer. He was standing at St. Paul's Chapel when first tower came down. "[It was] a nightmare. I thought we were already dead," he says. Now he suffers from, kidney cancer, for which he has had surgery, and precancerous conditions such as GERD | Photo by @dedecim #AssignmentNewsweek

9/11 (4/6): Dr. Michael Crane, 64, is the director of the World Trade Center Health Program’s clinical center at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York and treats more than 22,000 September 11 rescue and recovery workers. “The symptoms these patients have are terrifying,” he says. “They will suddenly wake up and find they cannot breathe” | Photo by @dedecim #AssignmentNewsweek

9/11 (3/6): Daisy Bonilla, 49, was one of the only women at the World Trade Center site and one of the youngest. She was 34 at the time of the attacks and a school safety agent for the NYPD. She patrolled Ground Zero for two months and looked after the morgues and orphaned children, as debris fell on her repeatedly. She retired last year due to health issues linked to contaminant exposure—today, she cannot walk without a walker, eats a liquefied diet, and suffers from precancerous GERD, Lupus and major circulatory issues in her legs. She believes no one should live or work near the WTC site and believes air and environment aren't safe | Photo by @dedecim #AssignmentNewsweek

9/11 (2/6): Richard Dixon, 50, has been a New York police officer for 30 years and has no plans to retire. He worked at the World Trade Center site for two months digging for survivors. He now suffers from numerous health issues including GERD, but can still work. Many of his colleagues from September 11 are now dead from cancer. “You don’t think that the cough you get today will be the cancer you get tomorrow... We lost 23 NYPD officers in the attacks,” he says. “But many more have died since then of these September 11–related illnesses. We need to find out why, or that list of names on the 9/11 memorial is going to just keep growing” | Photo by @dedecim #AssignmentNewsweek

9/11 (1/6): Retired telecoms manager and pilot Placido D. Perez, 59, was an EMS worker at the World Trade Center site. He was at the base of the towers when both planes hit, and remained there until they fell. Now, he suffers from numerous health issues including stage four liver swelling and PTSD. When he closes his eyes, he can still see the World Trade Center towers beneath him. On weekends, he would sometimes fly his red-and-white Cessna along the Hudson River, taking selfies with the towers in the background, stark against a cerulean sky. “I still look at the pictures all the time,” he says. “I remember the good times. It’s what gets you through” | Photo by @dedecim #AssignmentNewsweek

Clinton (3/4): The DNC Host Committee's art installation "Donkey's Around Town" places donkeys painted by local artists at popular sites and attractions throughout Philadelphia to represent the 57 delegations in the city for the Democratic National Convention | Photo by Newsweek's @michrichgorman, follow her all week for dispatches from the DNC.#AssignmentNewsweek
Clinton (2/4) DNC-themed souvenirs line the window of a shop on Arch Street | Photo by Newsweek's @michrichgorman, follow her all week for dispatches from the DNC.#AssignmentNewsweek

Clinton (1/4): A banner sign for Clinton sits against the wall during the DNC. Hillary Clinton made history this week by becoming the first female presidential canidate from a major party | Photo by Newsweek's @ninaburleigh, follow her all week for dispatches from the DNC.#AssignmentNewsweek

Trumpism (4/4): Anti-Clinton t-shirts and signs sprinkle the people and landscape in Ohio. During official speeches at the RNC, at times more time was devoted to attacking Clinton then supporting Trump as the nominee | Photo by Newsweek's @ninaburleigh, follow her all week for dispatches from the RNC. #AssignmentNewsweek

Trumpism (3/4): Vietnam vet Lou Pumphrey with a peace flag, in memory of his buddy who died in the Tet offensive at age 23 | Photo by Newsweek's @ninaburleigh, follow her all week for dispatches from the RNC. #AssignmentNewsweek

Trumpism (2/4): Nixons's son in law and New York State delegate Ed Cox, waiting for the Trumplings to give Donald J Trump, the nomination with New York's votes | Photo by Newsweek's @ninaburleigh, follow her all week for dispatches from the RNC. #AssignmentNewsweek

Quite! (6/6): The Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope searches the night sky. Run by the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, the telescope runs 24 hours a day observing different parts of the universe | Photo by @jimmcauley

Quite! (5/6): The view from Schou's front door. "No two of us are alike," Schou says, speaking about the symptoms EHS sufferers face. Sufferers report various symptoms, ranging from auditory tinnitus to gastrointestinal problems, that decrease their quality of life. Until recently, they rarely received serious consideration from medical professionals | Photo by @jimmcauley

Quite! (4/6): Schou takes her cage on wheels to the mechanic to be fixed up. Though her EHS symptoms have improved in Green Bank, she still uses the camper; she drove it to her son's wedding the following month in Maryland to shield herself from the cellular and wireless signals its guests would bring | Photo by @jimmcauley

Quiet! (3/6): Diane Schou, a Green Bank resident with EHS, set up a daybed in the middle of her house in Green Bank—rather than in its bedroom—to put more walls between her and the radiation of the outside world. When she isn't in the home, she travels in a camper she lined with protective foil shields, converting it into a homemade "Faraday cage," which limits electromagnetic interference. The camper served as her only shelter and living space for four to five years before she moved to Green Bank, having grown to view the five-by-12-foot space in which she lived as a prison | Photo by @jimmcauley

Quite! (2/6): Green Bank residents watch a little league game one meadow over from the National Radio Astronomy Observatory, where the Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope is located. The town's population is a mix of scientists who work at the neighboring facilities, families that have lived in the area for multiple generations and EHS sufferers | Photo by @jimmcauley

Quite! (1/6): The town of Green Bank, West Virginia, is a sleepy Appalachian town, the kind one might move to in order to escape the grind of urban centers and bustling suburbs. But its 143 residents didn't exactly move there for literal quiet. Green Bank is located in eastern West Virginia, in what's known as the National Radio Quiet Zone, where radio transmissions are heavily restricted and cellphones are scarce, all in service of actual radio silence for the Robert C. Byrd Green Bank Telescope—the world's largest steerable radio telescope, which opened in 2001. Any man-made interference limits its ability to “hear” information from the universe's farthest reaches, necessitating its location in Green Bank. The Quiet Zone was established in 1956, but it has drawn about 40 people over the past decade who suffer from electromagnetic hypersensitivity (EHS), given its lack of electromagnetic waves | Photo by @jimmcauley

"I am a teacher, a writer. My goal is to sensitize the desensitized, world leaders first among them. To be sensitive to people's pain, fears and hopes. I think that accomplishes quite a lot." — Elie #Wiesel in a 2006 interview with Newsweek. The acclaimed writer, Nobel Laureate, and holocaust survivor has died at 87 years old. | Photo by @Reuters
Sports? (6/6): The format of chessboxing is pretty simple: a round of chess followed by a round of boxing. That repeats until an opponent wins either by checkmate or knockout | Photo by @solneelman
Sports? (5/6): Kids playing bubble soccer at a birthday party in Rockwall, Texas, spend more time trying to knock over their friends than actually chasing the ball | Photo by @solneelman

Sports? (4/6): The "ball" in flaming tetherball is a roll of toilet paper soaked in 3 ounces of white gas, the stuff that saner people use in camp stoves and lanterns. It burns nice and bright, but without the obvious drawbacks of gasoline. That said, it's wise to avoid applying hairspray before playing and to keep a fire extinguisher or four nearby, as well as a liability waiver or two | Photo by @solneelman

Sports? (3/6): The friendly competition between Liberal, Kansas, and Olney, England, with women running down the streets of each town flipping pancakes, has been going on for more than 60 years. However, the first Pancake Day Race started in 1445, when a woman, who was late for church in Olney, ran to the service with skillet and pancake still in hand | Photo by @solneelman

Sports? (2/6): The most popular event at the annual Angola Prison Rodeo may very well be convict poker. After a bull is released into the arena, the last inmate not to leave the poker table is deemed "the winner" | Photo by @solneelman

Sports? (1/6): Sports have the power to unite or divide. With the NBA and NHL finals closing out, international soccer tournaments underway in the U.S. and France and the world descending on the Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, an ancient debate rears its head once again—what is sport? The upcoming Summer Olympics will feature 306 different events in 42 sports, according to Rio2016.com. But how many of those sports, such as synchronized swimming or equestrian events, do you consider a sport? For some, racing down a hill in a toy jeep is a sport. "There are no brakes other than your feet or your head," says event organizer Branndon Terry. In extreme Barbie jeep racing, riders sport motorcycle helmets for protection—and little else | Photo by @solneelman

Then and Now (14/14): From left, signs rest against a railing before a protest in New York on January 15, 2015; and an Atlanta sanitation worker, on strike, kneels at the grave of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. after a rally in Atlanta on April 4, 1970 | Photos by Andrew Kelly/Reuters; BJ/AP

Then and Now (13/14): Protests are often remembered at their most iconic: A flower in a gun barrel opposing war in Vietnam, a Black Power salute at the 1968 Olympics, a Tank Man in Tiananmen Square. But though an image can define a protest, the reverse is often true—especially in an age of live coverage and social media, where the world is constantly watching. At left, three young African-Americans raise their hands for the "hands up, don't shoot" gesture which helped galvanize #BlackLivesMatter; at right, police prepare to lift Mineral Bramletter in Brooklyn on July 10, 1963. The Congress of Racial Equality (CORE) was attempting to stop a cement truck from entering a hospital construction site. The protest stemmed from the lack of African Americans employed on the job | Photos by Reuters; Robert L. Greger/AP

Then and Now (12/14): From left, police corral protesters during a march in Los Angeles, California on November 26, 2014; and a 17-year-old African American civil rights activist is attacked by police dogs during a demonstration in Birmingham, Alabama on May 3, 1963 | Photos by Lucy Nicholson/Reuters; Bill Hudson/AP

Then and Now (11/14): Sit-ins at Woolworth lunch counters have been replaced with die-ins in New York’s Grand Central Station. #BlackLivesMatter tweets have replaced “I am a Man” sandwich cards. The national guard in Mississippi has been replaced by the national guard in Missouri. Through these diptychs, we can measure time and progress. By looking to the past, we glean insights toward the future, perhaps avoiding the pitfalls the next time around. At right, National Guard soldiers escort Freedom Riders along their ride from Montgomery to Jackson, Mississippi, in 1961 | Photos by AP; Bruce Davidson/Magnum

Then and Now (10/14): The previous years have brought to the headlines images of protest, unrest, questions about race and the reminder that despite the progress made over of the last century, America is far from a whole nation. Schools have been integrated, the workplace has laws to fight bigotry, the FBI keeps track of hate crimes, a biracial couple can eat Cheerios on a TV commercial, and a biracial man was elected twice to the highest post in the country. Progress has been made, but as the events of the past two years have reminded us, in many ways as it was, it still remains with many skin-deep issues still lingering under the surface. From left, protesters march through a suburb in St. Louis, Missouri on November 23, 2014, and at right, a man breaks down during a protest against segregation in May 1963 in Birmingham, Alabama | Photos by Adrees Latif/Reuters; Michael Ochs Archives/Getty

Then and Now (9/14): Leuna Rahman, 17, whose parents are from Bangladesh, identifies as South Asian. She says she faces criticisms of her skin color, even within her own family from her grandmother. "You hear it so often, you just give up on fighting back," Rahman says. "But I don’t let it get to me, because I learned to love myself." Rahman is often remidned of her skin, during the Paris attack, a friend sat down and said, ‘Can you tell your family not to kill my family? I heard Bengali people are also part of ISIS.’” She looks up with big, quizzical eyes. “Why would you just assume my family is a part of ISIS?” | Photo by @shaminder_dulai #AssignmentNewsweek

Then and Now (8/14): Loretta Eboigbe, 18, was born in Verona, Italy and moved to the U.S. in 2008. “I thought I’d be surrounded by diversity and people wouldn’t judge me based on how I looked," Eboigbe says. "If people are constantly throwing racist comments at you, especially at a young age, there’s no way to stand tall and be proud of who you are. ... I was always hoping that once I got to college it would stop, and I’d find people like me. But now I’m transitioning into a world that might be the same,” says Eboigbe, who’s going to Brown this fall. “To see racism happening on college campuses, people being victimized, it’s scary.” It’s a grim outlook: Nearly twice as many teens—and nearly three times as many black teens—think racial discrimination is here to stay, compared with 50 years ago. The internet has given them a front-row seat to some of the greatest civil rights moments of their young lives. They’ve witnessed injustice (Ferguson), outright racism against their president (61 percent of Trump supporters don’t believe Obama was born in the U.S.) and too little change coming too late (the Oscars) | Photo by @shaminder_dulai #AssignmentNewsweek

Then and Now (7/14): In 1966, Laura Richardson (then Laura Hausman) was passionate about Vietnam, the Bomb, civil rights and legalizing dope and homosexuality; she still is. “The gay marriage thing is great! We’ve done something right. I know marijuana will do some very interesting and positive things; it isn’t just about getting high,” she says. Yet she has harsh words for America’s “so-called election,” its health care system and overcrowded prisons, and the legal system, which she says is “run by very rich and usually white guys.” As for racism, “I don’t see a cure…. I think economic equality would make things a lot better, but that isn’t happening in this country.” Richardson moved from Boston to Berkeley, California, halfway through high school, she left behind her old friends and didn’t look back. “They were a bunch of perfect, first-class...finks,” she told Newsweek in 1966, when she was 17. At Berkeley High School, Richardson’s new friends were into discussing five topics: Vietnam, the Bomb, civil rights, marijuana and sex. “I really fit in here,” she said. A lot has changed in California's Bay Area, but the free spirit of Berkeley has endured she said. Her one piece of advice for young people reflects her regrets: “Educate yourselves. Oh, yes. In any way possible” | Photos by Eugene Anthony; @enlowphotos #AssignmentNewsweek

Then and Now (6/14): Christopher Reed was never one for labels. “I’ve always disdained the word teenager,” he toldNewsweek in 1966, when he was 17. He believed the word had “hostile connotations,” and he referred to teens as they rather than we. “People think anyone who’s a teenager is automatically a delinquent,” he said. “I don’t feel I’m a member of the vast portion of kids my age.” After a privileged upbringing on New York's Upper East Side, former Newsweek teen interviewee Christopher Reed chose a life focused on activism, the environment and education. Reed was an honors student at an elite Manhattan private school. He rarely smoked, avoided bars and, after graduating, went to Harvard. His professional life has revolved around local farming, the environment, activism and education. “I’ve always been open to the idea that the most interesting changes happen on a small scale—grassroots. Institutions can do something that isn’t top down, and that has real impact. So it’s not a surprise that I would have landed in a small community that would easily be overlooked yet has its own contribution to make to changing the world” | Photos by Steve Schapiro; @dedecim #AssignmentNewsweek

Then and Now (5/14): Tommy Brewer was a young man committed to education as a means to leave his gang-riddled Chicago neighborhood a little better then he found it. He made good on his promise by becoming a judge and now tries to lead other young men by example. When Newsweek spoke to him in the 1960s, Brewer was growing up in the projects of Chicago’s South Side. Brewer used to watch ABC’s The FBI on Sunday nights with his father. “I said one day, out of excitement, ‘I wanna be an FBI agent!’” recalls Brewer. “And my father said, ‘You’re not allowed in the FBI. They don’t allow blacks to be FBI agents.’” Brewer’s father was a steelworker with a sixth-grade education, and his mother didn’t make it past the fifth grade. But Brewer, surrounded by gangs and violence, was convinced an education would get him wherever he wanted to go in life. So each morning, he took two buses and an L train to Lindblom Technical High School, where he got A’s (and one B) and took honors courses. After high school he earned a scholarship to Williams College, got his law degree at Northwestern and, a couple of years later, joined the FBI. “At the time, there were 118 black agents out of almost 9,000. Me and another guy were one of the few from the North, both from public housing, and that was unheard of in the bureau,” he says | Photos by Deelan Haun; Patrick Mongoven #AssignmentNewsweek

Then and Now (4/14): Laura Jo Degan's life has taken some unexpected turns since appearing in Newsweek's 1966 issue, but she says teenagers have bizarre expectations such as thinking they're all going to be the next Mark Zuckerberg. As a 14-year-old growing up in Houston, Laura Jo Degan (formerly Davis) rode horses, played volleyball, volunteered at a local hospital and worried about boys. Yet this cheery surface masked a challenging childhood. Today, she cares for three relatives with Alzheimer's disease. Degan’s life has hardly been “ho-hum,” but when she reflects back, her memories are tinged with a wistful hint of regret. “I guess I’m where I’m supposed to be. But with that in mind, I think I should have—how can I say?—I could have done more with my life. I think you always feel [that way] when you’re reaching the end of life,” she says. “I’m looking at retirement now, and that’s pretty scary with the economy. So, I shoulda made a lot of money. That shoulda been my goal, but I never had those goals. I think my biggest goal was I wanted to be happy. I saw people who did not have a lot of joy. So I just want to be happy.” | Photos by Shel Hershorn; @photokayne #AssignmentNewsweek

Then and Now (3/14): Growing up on a farm in Newton, Iowa, (population 15,381) Bruce Curtis yearned for experiences beyond small-town life. He's spent over four decades working in the meatpacking industry, lived in 11 cities, and now resides in his family's old farmhouse with his wife, his high school sweetheart. When asked what advice he’d give young people today, he says, “That’s a good question. Boy...” Then he goes silent. After a long pause, he says, “I was fortunate with the environment I grew up in and the family background, and some teenagers probably don’t have that opportunity.” He’s also worried about drugs. When Curtis was in high school, he remembers some people drinking. “Today is scarier... To be honest, I’m not sure I’d want to go through [being a teen] again” | Photos by Charles Harbutt; Matt Curtis #AssignmentNewsweek

Then and Now (2/14): After appearing on the cover of Newsweek’s teen issue—blond, sun-kissed, seated on a motorcycle and flashing a killer smile—Jan Smithers received calls from “many, many” Hollywood agents hoping to represent her. Today, she’s most known for playing Bailey Quarters in WKRP in Cincinnati, which aired from 1978 to 1982. She was also married to actor James Brolin for nine years, but today she prefers life outside the spotlight. In regards to race, Smithers is trouble by how little progress has been made and says the key to solving discrimination and violence is “peace in your inner world" | Photos by Julian Wasser; @elissasylviamirzaei #AssignmentNewsweek

Then and Now (1/14): In 1966 Newsweek took a deep dive into the curious age of teen-agers, a relatively new social demographic, and asked teens what they cared about, wanted, owned, wished for the world and dove into topics as wide ranging as premarital sex to politics to race in America. 50 years later, we went back and found that teens had replaced transistor radios with streaming video, that political heroes had been replaced with pop idols and that race was still at the forefront of their minds. Today twice as many teens and three times as many black teens think racial discrimination is here to stay, compared with 1966. On Newsstands now | Photos by Julian Wasser; Gandee Vasan #AssignmentNewsweek

The Other Survivor (7/7): Gulab with two of his children in their apartment complex; his son Irshad, right, is now the family’s primary breadwinner, in part because his English is far better than that of his parents | Photo by @cooperneill #AssignmentNewsweek
The Other Survivor (6/7): A traditional Pashtun meal prepared by Gulab’s wife in the small four-bedroom apartment they all now share | Photo by @RMSchneiderman #AssignmentNewsweek

The Other Survivor (5/7): Gulab checks out at the grocery store. He is struggling to support his family but is relieved that he no longer has to worry about being ambushed by the Taliban | Photo by @cooperneill #AssignmentNewsweek

The Other Survivor (4/7): A photo of former Navy SEAL Marcus Luttrell dressed in traditional Afghan attire during his stay in the village of Sabray during the summer of 2005. For days, Gulab and his fellow villagers protected him from a Taliban-linked militia in northeastern Afghanistan. Luttrell went on to write the best-selling memoir, Lone Survivor. #AssignmentNewsweek

The Other Survivor (3/7): Gulab plays with his daugher in thier Texas home. In a futile attempt to hide from the Taliban, who were trying to kill him, Gulab left his village and moved to Asadabad, capital of Kunar Province. Eventually he and his family made their way to Fort Worth, Texas, where the family is living in a drab, four-bedroom apartment that costs them $719 a month | Photo by @cooperneill #AssignmentNewsweek

The Other Survivor (2/7): The Pashto and English alphabet hang on the wall of Gulab's home in Fort Worth, Texas on May 6, 2016. Gulab has found it hard to adjust with a language barrier which keeps him isolated. | Photo by @cooperneill #AssignmentNewsweek

The Other Survivor (1/7): Mohammad Gulab he has been hunted by the Taliban since 2005 for rescuing and protecting a critically wounded Navy SEAL in Afghanistan on a mission that went south. Gulab, the savior of Navy SEAL Marcus Luttrell, claims his book 'Lone Survivor' about the failed mission and his interactions with Gulab, got it wrong. The book became a NYT bestseller and was adapted into a movie that did over $150,000,000 at the box office staring Mark Wahlberg. Gulab on the other hand spent the last 10 years dodging assassination attempts by the Taliban and waiting for the U.S. to come save him and his family before finally getting a visa a few months ago. He is now living in an apartment for refugees with his wife and seven children struggling to adapt to a new country with a language he does not understand and no way to support his family. Read the story on newsstands today | Photo by @cooperneill #AssignmentNewsweek

Blooming Generation (8/8): Aper Armanovich, a member of the Guard of Honor of Karabakh, stands in Stepanakert a few yards from the cemetery for victims of the Karabakh War. Gravestones in the cemetery are only identified by the year of death. Though a ceasefire has been called, it is unknown how many more casualties will result from unresolved tensions | Photos by @karlitomancini and @gianmarcomaraviglia

Blooming Generation (7/8): Two new mothers and a newborn rest in the maternity ward of a hospital in Stepanakert. A child born in the NKR faces a future of conditional peace with Azerbaijan | Photos by @karlitomancini and @gianmarcomaraviglia

Blooming Generation (6/8): Intact buildings stand among heavily damaged buildings in the city center of Shushi. The city came under control of the NKR in 1992 after heavy fighting and has experienced little to no rebuilding, still bearing deep scars of war | Photos by @karlitomancini and @gianmarcomaraviglia

Blooming Generation (5/8): Anna Mnatsakanyan dances in the Stendhal Club, the only place open until late night in Stepanakert. Most young people in the NKR meet each other at home or have dinner in restaurants, as their more traditional parents disapprove of the club. In traditional Karabakh society, women are expected to stay at home and become mothers. A low birth rate means women feel pressure from the government to have as many children as possible | Photos by @karlitomancini and @gianmarcomaraviglia

Blooming Generation (4/8): Stepan Avanesyan, right, sits with his family in Madagis. Four of his six children attend the village's school, where Avanesyan works as a history teacher. The family fled Azerbaijan in 1988 at the beginning of the rising tensions | Photos by @karlitomancini and @gianmarcomaraviglia

Blooming Generation (3/8): Members of the Guard of Honor of the NKR Army in Stepanakert stand during the annual commemoration ceremony for the Sumgait pogrom, a massacre that targeted the Armenian population of the seaside town of Sumgait in Soviet Azerbaijan in late February 1988. Mobs made up largely of ethnic Azerbaijanis formed into groups and attacked and killed Armenians on the streets and in their apartments; widespread looting and a general lack of concern from police officers allowed the situation to continue for three days | Photos by @karlitomancini and @gianmarcomaraviglia

Blooming Generation (2/8): A group of female students check their class schedule during a break at Artsakh State University in the NKR. A degree here will only have value in the NKR and Armenia, since the NKR's self-declared independence has not been recognized by neighboring countries | Photos by @karlitomancini and @gianmarcomaraviglia

Blooming Generation (1/8): Children from a local private school visit the Tatik-Papik monument, also known as "We Are Our Mountains," which represents the Armenian heritage of Nagorno-Karabakh in Stepanakert, in the self-recognized Nagorno-Karabakh Republic. After years of bloody conflict with Azerbaijan for independence, the region's ethnic Armenian majority and Azerbaijan entered a cease-fire. The truce has since been shaken by violence many times, most recently on April 2 | Photos by @karlitomancini and @gianmarcomaraviglia

Iceberg Hunters (8/8): .After the fishing industry crashed, nearly 40,000 Newfoundlanders were out of work. Now, iceberg water, in plain bottled form for use in high-end vodka, is part of a small but growing industry and has become one of region's biggest emerging job sectors | Photo by #VeroniqueDeViguerie

Iceberg Hunters (7/8): Canadian Iceberg Vodka Corp. is one of many buyers for rare iceberg water and produces around 200,000 cases a year, up from the few thousand cases 20 years ago, says President and CEO David Meyers | Photo by #VeroniqueDeViguerie

Iceberg Hunters (6/8): It can take weeks for Kean’s team to find the ideal ’berg to bite.' Most of an iceberg is underwater, meaning danger can be hidden until it's too late to avoid. Treacherous, yes, but if the sea gives you ice, you might as well drink it, Kean says. Icebergs make top-notch water—and subsequently top-notch vodka | Photo by #VeroniqueDeViguerie

Iceberg Hunters (5/8): Danger is omnipresent—if an iceberg flips over, a boat can sink. The team also has learned to avoid icebergs that have “legs,” the limb-like protrusions that sometimes appear above water as the iceberg melts. These can give the floating ’bergs a less stable center of gravity and make them more likely to roll | Photo by #VeroniqueDeViguerie

Iceberg Hunters (4/8): On the boat life is full of waiting, and some crews have had close calls, making them extra cautious. “She looks dangerous. She can sleep,” said one member of Kean's crew, always referring to icebergs as female. Once an ideal iceberg is found, crews can day to weeks to harvest a boatload | Photo by #VeroniqueDeViguerie

Iceberg Hunters (3/8): Rarefied iceberg water is lucrative business in the premium water and liqueur industries. Vodka for instance, with its makeup of 40 percent alcohol and 60 percent water, is often touted by producers for its iceberg-water content as a selling point | Photo by #VeroniqueDeViguerie

Iceberg Hunters (2/8): Heavy machinery is used to harvest an iceberg. Icebergs that break free and float down from the Arctic can fetch a hefty sum for fishing crews willing to take on the danger and challenge. Iceberg water can be thousands of years old, composed of ancient snowfall, and is touted as more pure than modern water, which must contend with man-made pollution | Photo by #VeroniqueDeViguerie

Iceberg Hunters (1/8): Iceberg hunters have become the modern-day cowboys of the North and South Poles, with reality shows and news articles documenting the art of lopping off pieces of massive ice mountains that will be crushed into luxury water. Ed Kean and his crew make a living chasing icebergs at the top of the world, harvesting about 1,000 tons of ice per year, which crushes down to between 264,000 million and 343,000 million gallons of water | Photo by #VeroniqueDeViguerie

Nowhere to Run (8/8): A hallway inside the Habbaniya Tourist Village hotel, once a luxury resort for Iraqi vacationers. In recent months, hundreds of displaced families have sought shelter in the former resort, which is located between the war-torn cities of Ramadi and Fallujah. Hundreds of families have sought shelter in the dilapidated buildings, relying on the International Committee of the Red Cross and other humanitarian organizations for food and other relief items | Photo by #MoisesSaman @magnumphotos #AssignmentNewsweek

Nowhere to Run (7/8): Siham Sabah Mozin, 65, lies inside a tent next to her 6-year-old grandson, Qusay. They are among 4,000 families who have fled ISIS-controlled areas to shelter in a former resort complex by Lake Habbaniya, a few hours drive from Baghdad | Photo by #MoisesSaman @magnumphotos #AssignmentNewsweek

Nowhere to Run (6/8): Abda Dayeh Hamadi, 60, sits outside her tent at camp Markazi. Hamadi is a diabetic suffering from gangrene in her left foot and has lost all access to health care since fleeing Ramadi in January. Without access to a healthy diabetic diet, antibiotics or medicine her health is worsening | Photo by #MoisesSaman @magnumphotos #AssignmentNewsweek

Nowhere to Run (5/8): The Habbaniya Tourist Village, a former vacation spot 50 miles west of Baghdad, is now home to some 4,000 families from Ramadi and Fallujah who have fled the conflict with ISIS. The resort lacks basic infrastructure: People live here with no electricity, running water or sewage system | Photo by #MoisesSaman @magnumphotos #AssignmentNewsweek

Nowhere to Run (4/8): Sara Adnan Mohamed, 10, draws a picture in the house she shares with her family, in the predominantly Sunni village of Albu Ajeel. The village of 20,000 residents lies on the outskirts of the city of Tikrit, in Salahaddin Province, that fell to ISIS militants in June 2014 and was recaptured by Iraqi special forces in April 2015. After being displaced for more than a year, Sara and her family returned to Albu Ajeel only to find their village mostly destroyed and their home partially burned down | Photo by #MoisesSaman @magnumphotos #AssignmentNewsweek

Nowhere to Run (3/8): A man sells cotton candy in the Sunni-majority neighborhood of Adhamiya in Baghdad, now a temporary home for thousands of Sunnis displaced by fighting between ISIS and Iraqi forces. More than 10 percent of all Iraqis have fled their homes but remain stuck within the country | Photo by #MoisesSaman @magnumphotos #AssignmentNewsweek

Nowhere to Run (2/8): A girl stands between tents in the Markazi camp in Anbar Province. Most of the camp’s residents fled fighting between ISIS and Iraqi special forces in Ramadi. According to the U.N. refugee agency, which opened the camp in October, more than 250,000 civilians have fled Ramadi since April 2015, but most of them have remained inside Anbar Province itself—living in schools and unfinished buildings or with relatives. Few families in the camp have any source of income, and many are in desperate need of health care and other aid | Photo by #MoisesSaman @magnumphotos #AssignmentNewsweek

Nowhere to Run (1/8): Balasim, a Sunni villager, holds a young boy as he stands in a burned-out house in Albu Ajeel, a village in Salahaddin Province. The boy’s mother was killed after stepping on a land mine as she tried to flee an ISIS-controlled area near Hawija, north of Baghdad. Balasim carried the boy in his arms for the entire journey to Albu Ajeel, and he was photographed shortly after reaching the relative safety of this village | Photo by #MoisesSaman @magnumphotos #AssignmentNewsweek

False Teachings (11/11): A former talibé plays in the courtyard of a temporary shelter in Bafata, Guinea-Bissau. "Now we are seeing Koranic teachers giving away their talibés because they are afraid to be taken to court and eventually being convicted, is not only by the prison itself, but it's a matter of shame to them if they have to go a courthouse.… Sometimes it's really difficult to reintegrate the children in their families, many of them don't even know who their parents are," says Malam Ciro, director of the shelter | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

False Teachings (10/11): Senegal and neighboring governments are attempting to clamp down on the practice. Guinea-Bissau, to the south of Senegal, has sent its military on patrols to break up human-trafficking rings. In June 2015, the Guinean military police came across a group of children walking through a forest area near the border. In March 2015, Guinea-Bissau authorities found 54 children hidden inside five vehicles that were crossing the border to Senegal. Despite successes of its neighbors, Senegalese authorities continue to fail to prosecute the traffickers | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

False Teachings (9/11): Runaway talibés stand on the bank of a Senegal river. The Saint Louis area is known as "talibés city," due to the high number of runaways who choose to stay on the remote streets there instead of daaras | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

False Teachings (8/11): Talibés sleep together inside a daara in Saint Louis, north of Senegal. The daara with over 30 children has no clean water and unreliable electricity. Children sleep on the concrete floor without any protection. Every year, Senegal observes National Talibé Day on April 20 and the government discusses the situation, but progress has been slow | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

False Teachings (7/11): Talibés read the Koran inside a daara in Medina district of Dakar. They have to memorize different parts of the Koran each day before going to the streets to beg for money and food for their guardians. Many of these Koranic schools are in buildings that were never completed and often have poor sanitary conditions and malaria, skin diseases, breathing problems and stomach parasites are common | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

False Teachings (6/11): Aida Diouf with her daughter inside their one-bedroom house in Dakar. She had to give away her son to a daara after her husband died, as she couldn't afford to raise both children. "Life is hard in Senegal," she says. "I never thought having to choose between my children, but there was no other option. I know I'll never see my son again, but I believe he's well and that he'll have a good life" | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

False Teachings (5/11): Talibés read the Koran inside a daara in Dakar. Some marabouts have more than one daara, having control of more than 100 young boys. There is little fear of prosecution from the law in the practice for the marabouts, and more are setting up shop each year | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

False Teachings (4/11): A man gives money to talibe children in the holy city of Touba. Talibés are common at gas stations, as the steady flow of people allows them many opportunities to beg. For a marabout, more boys means more income | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

False Teachings (3/11): A young talibé is bound by chains in an isolation area of a daara in Touba. In this daara the youngest talibés are shackled by their ankles to stop them from running away. These children can stay like that for days, weeks, even months until they gain the marabout's trust. Their guardian explains, "When I release them, I give them the freedom to beg like the rest of the talibés" | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

False Teachings (2/11): Ibrahima Ndao, a marabout of a daara in Rufisque, whips a talibé child after he read an excerpt of the Koran incorrectly, May 17, 2015. Physical punishment is not out of the ordinary for talibés when they fail to get the daily quota imposed by the marabout or if they make a mistake reading the Koran | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

False Teachings (1/11): In Senegal, boys aged 5-15 are often held in captivity at Koranic boarding schools, also known as daaras, where under the guise of studying the Koran, school leaders force the boys to beg in the streets for eight hours a day and being them food and money. Parents often send their children unwittingly to daaras simply because they can't afford education, committing them to a life of exploitation and abuse. In addition to being forced to beg, the talibés are beaten, raped by their marabouts or older talibés, chained to the ground so they can't run away, and live in overcrowded and unsanitary conditions | Photo by @_mariocruzphoto

Harper Lee wasn't born a famous author or Presidential Medal of Freedom recipient. And she still joked about meeting real authors—her peers—after 30,000 copies of 'To Kill A Mockingbird' were already sold, a book Newsweek called "a melting and witty treatment of a refreshingly undepraved Southern childhood" in 1961. 
Harper Lee's natural brilliance fused with an incredible attention to detail—and a fervor to write about racism and injustice against the wishes of critics. 

Here's an incredible true story on how Lee approached one harsh commenter, from the same Newsweek profile: 

"Snowed under with fan letters, Harper Lee is stealing time from a new novel-in-progress to write careful answers. Her favorite letter, a little out of the mold, is a roasting from a crank in Oklahoma who heard she was guilty of writing a novel in which an innocent Negro is convicted of raping a moronic white woman. 'In this day of mass rape of white women who are not morons,' her accuser demanded, 'why is it that you young Jewish authors seek to whitewash the situation?' Will this rate an answer, too? 'Oh, yes,' said the author—who is kin to Robert E. Lee. 'I think I'll say, 'Dear Sir or Madam, somebody is using your name to write dirty letters. You should notify the FBI.' And I'm going to sign it, Harper Levy.'"

The New Europeans (11/11): From left, Khalil Saleh, Essam Arafah, Razan Arafah, Salsabil Kreker, Lubna Kreker, Somar Kreker, Ghalia Sale (Mousab’s wife) and her brother Mohammed Saneh dig into a meal at Mousab’s house. Before he arrived, Kreker called his brother. “We need food. We need salad,” he said. Two weeks of living off canned and boxed goods had left the family craving a home-cooked meal. Like so many refugees, they are in limbo, waiting for residency papers and unable to work or study until the permits arrive. “I miss my mother and father in Syria,” Kreker says. “There’s little to do here, but we have hot water, we have electricity, and we are safe.” | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek

The New Europeans (10/11): Kreker looks on as another refugee shows him how to buy a ticket for Schwäbisch Gmünd, where his brother lives. Once in Germany, it took Kreker two days to find his brother. His sisters, he recalls, “were so tired and disappointed.” He was afraid the German police would send him and his family to a refugee camp. They were all exhausted. The siblings’ reunion was tearful—Kreker had not seen his brother since Mousab left Syria a year earlier. The chicken and rice Mousab cooked for the famished travelers was both a taste of home and reminder of all that they had left behind | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek

Today is Newsweek's 83rd birthday! 🎉

News-Week first published its first issue on this day, February 17, 1933. President Herbert Hoover presided over a nation reeling from the devastating poverty caused by the Great Depression. Across Atlantic waters in Germany, Chancellor Adolf Hitler, flanked by “blazing Nazi banners,” spoke to ever larger crowds. 
More than 8 decades later, News-Week is now simply Newsweek—and we're feeling younger than ever, committed to carry on the work of journalism in the coming century.

The New Europeans (9/11): Razan Arafah and her cousin Lubna Kreker have an eye-opening first trip to an Austrian supermarket. For the first time since arriving in Europe, the pair were free of police harassment, and food was plentiful. “They were so happy, because they could buy anything,” Kreker says. “Austria was the best.” | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek
The New Europeans (8/11): After five hours of traveling, Salsabil gets off the train. She complains of being too tired and fatigued to carry on | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek

The New Europeans (7/11): Kreker and his sister Salsabil eat canned food and wait for sunrise in a camp in Macedonia. When the sun comes up, they will leave the camp, which sits close to the border with Serbia. Ahead lies a long walk along the train tracks, and Kreker wants to walk in daylight to make sure his family is visible when trains thunder past | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek

The New Europeans (6/11): As the eldest of the group, he became its de facto leader, determined to reach his brother Mousab’s house in Schwäbisch Gmünd, southern Germany. On the train, Kreker remembers thinking, “OK, in two days I’ll be in Germany; the rest will be easy.” He still had nine days of travel to go, but the worst was over | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek

The New Europeans (5/11): As he heads for the Serbian border, Kreker looks out of the window of the train the family has taken from Macedonia to Serbia. As they crossed border after border, the family members were constantly afraid of being detained—and yet their spirits remained high as they made their way toward Europe. “I thought, OK, we’ve done it, we’ve arrived,” Kreker says, speaking by phone from Germany about the moment the boat they were in touched the Greek shoreline | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek

The New Europeans (4/11): Miscellaneous objects and money from Kreker's pockets; this is everything that he carried on him during the trip. As they crossed border after border, the family members were constantly afraid of being detained—and yet their spirits remained high as they made their way toward Europe. “I thought, OK, we’ve done it, we’ve arrived,” Kreker says, speaking by phone from Germany about the moment the boat they were in touched the Greek shoreline. The eldest of the group, he became its de facto leader, determined to reach his brother Mousab’s house in Schwäbisch Gmünd, southern Germany | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek

The New Europeans (3/11): From Athen's Kreker and his sisters, Salsabil and Lubna, used buses to get closer to Macedonia’s borders, their next major hurdle on the way to Germany. Their journey took them from Turkey to Greece, Macedonia, Serbia, Croatia, Slovenia, Austria and finally Germany. They went by train and by bus and on foot—through heat and cold, accepting food from aid organizations and facing hostility from some of the police they encountered in the Balkans | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek

The New Europeans (2/11): When Turkish police refused to let them cross, Kreker and his family decided to make the more dangerous route to Greece, via boat. Kreker and his family are among the well over 1 million refugees who have come to Europe in 2015. They have fled war and economic hardship in countries across Africa and the Middle East in the hope of finding safety. While these new Europeans settle in, communities across the continent are adjusting to the newcomers—sometimes happily, sometimes with suspicion and resentment | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek

The New Europeans (1/11): Somar Kreker and his sister Lubna sit on the Turkish side of Turkey’s border with Greece. They and three other members of their family waited there for a week for the land crossing to reopen. In a few months the 27-year-old Syrian refugee and his sisters will reach the German town of Mosbach, and finally have a place he can call home. Beginning in October, Kreker, his two sisters and their two cousins made the perilous journey to Europe, taking a month and a half to reach Germany from their starting point in Istanbul. Kreker arrived in the Turkish city from Jordan; his family from their village near the Syrian capital of Damascus | photo by @alessio_mamo #AssignmentNewsweek

White Helmets (6/6): The volunteers say they often run toward a scene fully acknowledging that bombs may still be falling. Five years into Syria's civil war, the country's Syrian Civil Defense workers have saved more than 40,000 lives on both sides of the fight | Photo by @nicoletung #AssignmentNewsweek

White Helmets (5/6): The White Helmets—the largest civil society group in Syria and one that is nonsectarian, neutral and unarmed—are made up of Syrians from Aleppo and Idlib—former students, teachers, vegetable sellers and farmers. After the training, they will teach newly recruited emergency workers back home | Photo by @nicoletung #AssignmentNewsweek

White Helmets (4/6): The Syrian Civil Defense numbers at roughly 2,500 members throughout various cities and villages in the country. At least 150 have been killed in the line of duty, and four times as many have suffered serious injuries, many as a result of secondary bombs that land on the site they have responded to initially | Photo by @nicoletung #AssignmentNewsweek

White Helmets (3/6): Instructors relax in their rooms at night following a long day of training in southern Turkey, on December 13, 2015. They say indiscriminate targeting of civilian areas all over Syria have forced them to fill the void of emergency responders, simultaneously becoming firefighters, paramedics, and search and rescue teams | Photo by @nicoletung #AssignmentNewsweek

White Helmets (2/6): Instructors of the White Helmets, or the Syrian Civil Defense, during a training course in southern Turkey, on December 13 and 14. Volunteers are filling the void of emergency responders, simultaneously becoming firefighters, paramedics, and search and rescue teams during the ongoing Syrian Civil War. From top left: Samer Hossein (30, from Idlib, Syria), Ali (40, from Aleppo), Khaled (40, from Idlib, Syria), Yusuf Azzo (27, from Heyyan, Syria), Mahmoud Hatter (27, from Aleppo, Syria), and Husam (25, from Binnish, Syria) | Photo by @nicoletung #AssignmentNewsweek

White Helmets (1/6): During a 5-week course, team leaders from Syria's White Helmets, or the Syrian Civil Defense, are trained in southern Turkey to be instructors for other Syrian Civil Defense volunteers inside the country | Photo by @nicoletung #AssignmentNewsweek
The Big Melt (11/11): When we dream of Antarctica, pop culture always see Emperors, but the South Pole is so much more. (But also penguins) #AssignmentNewsweek

The Big Melt (10/11): To avoid transmission of invasive species from other parts of the world to the Antarctic Peninsula, all clothing and equipment must be decontaminated before leaving the ship with vacuums, boot scrubbers and a special chemical bath for boots. Of special interest to crew members who perform this function, are seeds and organic matter. After completing the process, each expedition member must sign a “Decontamination Declaration Form” as part of the Antarctic Treaty | Photo by @CharlieWittmack #AssignmentNewsweek

The Big Melt (9/11): Antarctica has become significantly more accessible over the 100 years since Shackleton’s historic expedition. Here, the three year-old daughter of the ship’s Safety Officer is being carried by her father up the ridge at Half Moon Bay | Photo by @CharlieWittmack #AssignmentNewsweek

The Big Melt (7/11): : Connor Ryan, a Naturalist on the National Geographic Explorer, takes guests on a zodiac cruise through the ice bergs surrounding Cuvehrville Island off the Antarctic Peninsula | Photo by @CharlieWittmack #AssignmentNewsweek

The Big Melt (6/11): At the end of every day, expedition leaders aboard the ship trace a line on a large map laid out on a table in the chart room, indicating where we'd been. | Photo by @NinaBurleigh #AssignmentNewsweek
The Big Melt (5/11): Emperor penguins on the Weddell Sea | Photo by @CharlieWittmack #AssignmentNewsweek

The Big Melt (4/11): : Penguins can often be spotted among the ice floats in the Weddell Sea. Newsweek's reporting team immediately spotted one of the birds, and "with the intuition that he might be leading us somewhere, we began to follow. After a two-mile hike we reached the colony and found more than twenty Emperors enjoying a beautiful day on the fast ice," writes photojournalist @CharlieWittmack #AssignmentNewsweek

The Big Melt (3/11): An iceberg floating in the waters of Cierva Cove, on the West coast of Graham Land, Antarctica. Icebergs are seductively beautiful, but to be avoided by small crafts because they shatter without warning | Photo by @NinaBurleigh #AssignmentNewsweek

#NewsweekRewind: With President @barackobama delivering his final State of the Union today, we thought we'd use the occasion to head back to 1983 and read an archived article titled "State of the Union: Reagan at Midterm" which  proves just how little American partisan politics have changed in 40-plus years. The biggest political issue du jour was government spending versus taxes. Today, President Obama is expected to drive home the case that that federal reforms like Obamacare have helped Americans—and how he intends to pass along his legacy to the next president. Opponents have cried foul at how the president has handled such reforms, and crying foul is mere tradition in Washington. 
Here's an excerpt: "A new Newsweek Poll reveals that the president's approval rating has dipped to 38 percent, its lowest level ever; 50 percent of those polled disapprove of the way Reagan is handling the presidency." ... "The president is likely to emerge from the budget wrangle with at least two of his most treasured proposals intact— the third year of his tax reduction and increased defense spending. His aides predict that the debate with help nurture an image of Reagan as a president who faced up to all the hard decisions, yet, as one puts it, 'artfully stuck to his principles'" | Photo by Bruce Hoertel/Newsweek

#RonaldReagan #SOTU #WhiteHouse #Obama #Newsweek #OTD
The Big Melt (2/11): The snow capped peak of Cuverville Island, one of the few places where heading out in an inflatable raft is considered safe | Photo by @CharlieWittmack #AssignmentNewsweek

Ghost Town (7/7): According to state officials, the leak could be plugged as soon as March, nearly six months after it began. Drilling down the 8,500 feet to the source of the leak has been a challenge as going too fast would puncture adjust pipes carrying gas, according to SoCalGas | Photo by @patrickfallon #AssignmentNewsweek

Ghost Town (6/7): Tire skid marks cover an intersection between a housing development, left, and Porter Ranch Community School. Schools have been closed for weeks and at times the Porter Ranch is more of a ghost town then the thriving escape from Los Angeles it was billed as. On January 6, California declared a state of emergency for the environmental disaster | Photo by @patrickfallon #AssignmentNewsweek

Ghost Town (5/7): Alexandra Nagy, an organizer with Food & Water Watch speaks about a plan to "Shut It All Down" as residents including Matt Pakucko, president and co-founder of #SavePorterRanch, center right, and Kyoko Hibino, rear right, look on, during a board meeting for the group, January 3 | Photo by @patrickfallon #AssignmentNewsweek

Ghost Town (4/7): Vehicles drive past machinery at the #SoCalGas Aliso Canyon Storage Facility at sunset, December 30, 2015. The company has relocated residents who have complained about the smell of gas, as it promised to plug the #leak within months | Photo by @patrickfallon #AssignmentNewsweek

Ghost Town (3/7): A flyer for "Smell Something? Say Something." warns Porter Ranch residents of the leak. #Naturalgas has been spewing out at a rate of up to 100,000 pounds per hour since October, according to state officials | Photo by @patrickfallon #AssignmentNewsweek

Ghost Town (2/7): Co-founders of Save #PorterRanch Kyoko Hibino, left, and Matt Pakucko sit on their couch with their cats. The pair are trying to raise awareness of the nearly three month old gas leak and urge lawmakers to act. SoCalGas is currently drilling a relief well that is expected to take months to complete and plug the leak | Photo by @patrickfallon #AssignmentNewsweek

Ghost Town (1/7): Homes stand in a Porter Ranch housing development, January 3. Methane gas leaks from the #SoCalGas Aliso Canyon Storage Facility well SS-25 in Porter Ranch have forced many residents to abandon their homes | Photo by @patrickfallon #AssignmentNewsweek

A journalist checks out a virtual reality headset at the HTC booth at the Las Vegas Convention Center for #CES2016, one of the world's largest exhibitions of consumer products ranging from TV and wearable tech to Self-Driving cars and virtual reality games. Paris in Mourning (6/6): A man and woman embrace at a bus stop adorned with signs on November 15, as authorities continue to search for suspects in the attacks | Photo by Sarah Caron #AssignmentNewsweek

Paris in Mourning (5/6): Amid heightened security French policemen stand guard at the Eiffel Tower, which continues to remain closed after attacks across #Paris | Photo by Sarah Caron #AssignmentNewsweek

Paris in Mourning (4/6): Shattered glass and bullet holes mark the laundry shop between the Café Bonne Bière and the restaurant La Casa Nostra, one of the sites attacked by militants. Five people were killed and 8 injured here | Photo by Sarah Caron #AssignmentNewsweek

Paris in Mourning (3/6): Members of the Gendarmerie (akin the U.S. National Guard) verify the IDs of residents of the Rue du Faubourg-Saint-Honoré, which leads to the #French president's official residence at the Élysée Palace. Security has tightened across the country following the declaration of a state of emergency | Photo by Sarah Caron #AssignmentNewsweek

Paris in Mourning (2/6): A tri-colored sketch of a weeping #Marianne, the symbol of the French revolution sits amid flowers and candles in front of the Café Bonne Bièrein | Photo by Sarah Caron #AssignmentNewsweek

Paris in Mourning (1/6): Gunmen and suicide bombers killed at least 129 people and wounded around 350 people at six sites in the French capital on November 13. Days later Parisians continued to light candles and lay flowers in memory of the victims of Friday's deadly terror attacks in #Paris. A makeshift memorial in front of A theater, where 89 people were killed, became a place to mourn together | Photo by Sarah Caron #AssignmentNewsweek

#NewsweekCover: "America, Heal Thyself" The world through Dr. Ben Carson's surgical magnifying glass. His friends know @realbencarson as a brilliant surgeon and a generous man. So why does the surging #Republican candidate say so many crazy, inflammatory things? | Read the story at Newsweek.com
#NewsweekCover: The sometimes hysterical debate on #immigration reform is missing one important element: the truth | Read the story at Newsweek.com

Why do some animals get #cancer and some don't? Researchers are trying to study the tumor-suppressing gene TP53 to see if humans can adopt the same genetic benefits that cancer-resistant animals like the #elephant have. Read our cover story—on newsstands and online now!

#Elephants don't get #cancer—and scientists think they know why. Researchers are studying cancer mortality rates in various animals—dogs are more susceptible to cancer, but not elephants—to see why that is and what it could mean for humans. Read our latest cover story at Newsweek.com

Mars on Earth (5/5): A star observatory high above the volcano #MaunaKea. The environment is devoid of light pollution, making it an ideal place for stargazing and recreating the vast isolation of a possible #Mars landing. In the coming months @NASA will compile the results of the study and make recommendations for optimizing crew schedules and mission performance for a potential mission to Mars | Photo by @gaiasquarci #AssignmentNewsweek

Mars on Earth (4/5): Chairs are set up outside on the last day of the experiment. During the confinement, the #NASA crew would adventure out of the dome wearing full suits with internal oxygen ventilation—simulating a #Mars expedition. On this day, the researchers felt the sun and ate fresh fruit for the first time in eight months | Photo by @gaiasquarci #AssignmentNewsweek

Mars on Earth (3/5): A salt shaker in the shape of an astronaut inside the dome. During their isolation, the researchers only had as much food, clothing and knickknacks as they came with, making kitschy items like this a welcome addition. #NASA also organized outreach for schools to spread knowledge about the mission and the researchers maintained a blog to inform the public about their day-to-day activities | Photo by @gaiasquarci #AssignmentNewsweek

Mars on Earth (2/5): Jocelyn Dunn adjusts her spacesuit for a walk outside of the dome. While living on the volcano, the researchers try to behave as if they were on #Mars as much as possible—taking the same precautions they would on the far away planet before going outside | Photo by @gaiasquarci #AssignmentNewsweek

Mars on Earth (1/5): Jocelyn Dunn walks across a ridge atop Mauna Loa, #Hawaii. She's part of a team of six researchers simulating what it may be like to travel to #Mars. For eight months Dunn has lived in a dome, cut off from outsiders in the crater of the volcano as part of a #NASA study. The unearthly environment is an ideal setting to monitor the psychological response of human beings in conditions of isolation | Photo by @pascalperich #AssignmentNewsweek

Phony #Medicine: The fake drug industry is booming, deadly and hard to stop. A fractured regulatory system hampered by #BigPharma’s meddling has led to a growing global falsification market | Read our latest cover story at Newsweek.com

3,907 Days (5/5): #MichelleKnight poses for a photograph with #NBA commentator Mark Jackson in #Cleveland on June 16, 2015. Knight says she's often recognized while walking around her community. | Photo by @dustin_franz #AssignmentNewsweek

3,907 Days (4/5): Elaine Cagle speaks with @iMichelleKnight through video chat and wipes away tears as they share their experiences of traumatic abuse. Cagle survived a similar situation and reached out to Knight after following her story in the news. “I would really like to talk to her,” Cagle said before the call. "I think she has a lot of courage...Probably a lot more than me.” | Photo by @dustin_franz #AssignmentNewsweek

Is The Pope #Catholic? Of course he is. You just wouldn't know it from his press clips. This is our cover story about the liberal Pope, the stern archbishop, and the battle for the heart of Catholic #SanFrancisco | Read the story at Newsweek.com

3,907 Days 3/5: #MichelleKnight tattooed her chest with a baby and the phrase “Too beautiful for this Earth.” Knight got pregnant five times during her 11 years of captivity in Ariel Castro's house. Castro punched and starved her until she miscarried every pregnancy | Photo by @dustin_franz #AssignmentNewsweek

3,907 Days 2/5: Ariel Castro, the #Cleveland school bus driver who was convicted for abducting, imprisoning and repeatedly raped Knight and two other women, was convicted and sentenced to life in prison without parole, plus 1,000 years in 2013. A month after his sentencing, Castro was found dead in his cell, hanging from his bed sheet with his pants and underwear around his ankles. It was ruled a suicide | Photo by Aaron Josefczyk/Reuters

3,907 Days 1/5: In 2002, @iMichelleKnight was abducted and held captive inside Ariel Castro's home where she was beaten, starved, tortured and raped for over a decade. Now, two years after she was rescued, Knight is reaching out to other victims and survivors as part of a support network | Photo by @dustin_franz #AssignmentNewsweek

@imichelleknight is famous for surviving 11 years of brutal rape and torture at the hands of Ariel Castro. But after she was rescued, what happens then?
Life after 11 years of captivity, rape and torture: This is #MichelleKnight's story | Read our cover story at Newsweek.com

Before that album, Jackson released #Thriller, which was, and still is, one of the best-selling albums of all time.
