One of the more than 200 couples gathered in #TimesSquare on Friday, locking lips to mark the 70th anniversary of the iconic #VJDay "kiss" photograph #KissTSq | Read the story at Newsweek.com

Tunnel Vision 5/5: A #migrant climbs over a perimeter fence in an attempt to board a train. The U.K. government agreed to fund 100 extra guards near the Eurotunnel terminal in France after a meeting held on Monday evening. British Foreign Secretary Philip Hammond said the U.K. has 'got a grip' on the crisis. In an effort to show the U.K. is not a “land of milk and honey,” the government plans to remove benefits given to asylum-seeking families if their asylum applications are rejected, said immigration minister James Brokenshire.

Tunnel Vision 4/5: French officers try to stop migrants from reaching the Channel Tunnel, July 29. Thousands from Africa and the Middle East have traveled on foot and hitchhiked across Europe to the French entrance of the tunnel, in the hope of finding safety and jobs in the relatively prosperous U.K. Facing growing concern within his Conservative Party over the crisis, British Prime Minister David Cameron pledged to send fencing and trained sniffer dogs to help French authorities who patrol the border. The migrants have claimed they are escaping violence at home from places like Liberia and Syria and see England's thriving economy as their best chance at establishing a new life. The journey is not without its dangers; in the past six weeks, nine migrants have died trying to cross the English Channel by train or on roadways, compared with 15 total migrant deaths in 2014.

On the stump with Donald Trump. For years Trump's bombastic self-promotion had been an amusing sideshow in politics. Nobody's laughing now, and to explain why, Newsweek called on staff writer Bill Powell, who has known and covered Trump for 30 years. His dispatch from the front lines of the most amazing exasperating campaign the GOP has ever seen may make you laugh. Or cry.

Tunnel Vision 3/5: Two migrants walk through the "New Jungle" migrant camp. Migrants have been arriving at the camps for months and most stay on average for four months, according to French police, although it's not known if they head to other parts of Europe or successfully cross into the U.K. #Calais has had a migrant camp in some form for the past 15 years, but the New Jungle is larger and has an informal economy that includes schools and other community services. More recently additional smaller camps have sprung up near the tunnel, which migrants have used for rest before attempting to cross the tunnel or to regroup after failed attempts.

Tunnel Vision 2/5: Migrants use trees in #Calais to cross a fence to catch a train to reach England. Last week a Sudanese man, in his late-20s, was crushed under a truck as up to 1,500 migrants tried to force their way into the tunnel. The tunnel is one of the only ways to cross into the U.K. from France and many consider it their best chance to get there.

The first prime time #Republican 2016 presidential debate is underway. Who do you think came out ahead? Candidates from left to right: New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, U.S. Senator Marco Rubio, Dr. Ben Carson, Wisconsin Governor Scott Walker, businessman Donald Trump, former Florida Governor Jeb Bush, former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee, U.S. Senator Ted Cruz, U.S. Senator Rand Paul and Ohio Governor John Kasich | Photo by Aaron Josefczyk

Tunnel Vision 1/5: Police guard a road against #migrants hoping to enter the Eurotunnel terminal, near the French port city, Calais on July 30. Once inside the terminal, they will try to illegally board trains bound for England though the #channeltunnel. Thousands of migrants and refugees living in makeshift camps in Calais are making nightly attempts to enter the Channel Tunnel freight terminal to reach Britain.

Curing Cancer: In our special health issue we explore the challenges and innovations in #cancer treatment and research, from radio-waves and #nanotechnology to the debate over rising drug costs | On newsstands now

The Other Havana 6/6: A woman poses for a portrait at her neighbor’s home in El Cerro in #Havana. In Cuba neighbors and family members often arrive unannounced, so keeping a clean home and being presentable is very important to #Cubans. This upkeep doesn't come from a place of vanity among Cubans- rather, it's their ability to find a sense of pride, despite their occasional, bleak surroundings | Photo by @lisettepoole

The Other Havana 5/6: A horse rests after feeding on the grass outside a #Soviet-style apartment building in Nuevo Vedado, Havana. These buildings were made specifically to solve housing problems, without aesthetics in mind. Residents improvise to make their homes look comfortable and beautiful. | Photo by @lisettepoole

The Other Havana 4/6: A teenager hugs his girlfriend after swimming in a flooded amphitheater on the outskirts of Havana. After swimming, the first thing he did was fix his hair, making sure it was standing straight up. #Beauty rituals are not private in Cuba and often shared between couples, family and friends. | Photo by @lisettepoole

The Other Havana 3/6: Young people play dominoes at a house party, in a backyard in Santo Suarez, #Havana. This particular group and neighborhood are made up of Cuba’s “upper-middle class,” who have access to funds from abroad, and often items like Ray Bans and Yankees hats. As in most places, clothing is a way Cubans identify each other’s economic status. | Photo by @lisettepoole

The Other Havana 2/6: State-run hair salons used to be the only way to get your hair straightened or styled. But with the rise of the private sector, these businesses are becoming obsolete. To be Cuban is to control what you can, even if it means spending half your weekly salary on hair, fake nails or a new shirt. Some Cubans may not be able to remodel their homes, but they can buy a new pair of shoes and feel a bit better about their lives. | Photo by @lisettepoole

The Other Havana 1/6: There is much more to the city of Havana than old cars and broken buildings. Those exist, but so does a dedication to style. Being primped and pressed is important at all times, as is keeping a clean home. Photojournalist Lisette Poole has lived in #Cuba for years and brings us an a look at a less cliche Cuba. The streets of the Cuban capital reveal a city committed to preserving appearances and homes, even if some of those houses are falling down. | Photo by @lisettepoole

The second amendment gives citizens the right to bear arms, but not just any arms. Everyone agrees that gun control needs revisiting but why is it so hard to have a conversation about it? Should we ban certain accessories like large capacity drums? Should we make background checks mandatory? Should we stop pretending that change will come and sit down at the table to talk?

Adrift 6/6: A young Christian migrant from Nigeria, who says he fled because of the #militant group Boko Haram, sleeps with his stuffed toys at a church in the center of Lampedusa. Many churches opened their doors to migrants after a visit by Pope Francis to the island. The Catholic charity Caritas offers shelter, food, clothing and stuffed toys to the migrants, many of whom are traumatized by their journey. It remains to be seen what will become of them or what future migrants will have in Europe. | Photo by Sarah Caron

Sampling the goods at @wexlersdeli in L.A.'s Grand Central Market. Today's menu: The MacArthur Park sandwich, salmon and chocolate egg cremes. Read the story of @pmejia09's fall from staunch vegetarian to meat-eater with the help of #LA #foodie historian Josh Kun | Newsweek.com

Adrift 5/6: A group of #Eritreans traveling together to Pozzallo, south of Sicily, escaped from the migrant reception center to reach the city of Catania by bus, in the hopes that a smuggler would eventually take them to Sweden. If Europe’s migration handlers are making money off the newcomers, and more migrants mean more cash for the Mafia and its corrupt political allies, it leads some to question if Europe actually fueling the crisis. | Photo by Sarah Caron

Adrift 4/6: Aniweta, a Nigerian #immigrant, is paid to keep an eye on a parked car in Palermo. Many migrants work as parking attendants in cities around Sicily. Europe has reacted hesitantly to the flood of migrants attempting to cross the Mediterranean. | Photo by Sarah Caron

Adrift 3/6: A Nigerian immigrant is examined in a mobile hospital set up by Emergency, a nongovernmental organization that moves between different immigrant centers, providing medical and psychological aid to survivors of shipwrecks. Many suffer from post-traumatic stress. In 2014, more than a quarter of a million migrants tried to cross the #Mediterranean, of whom 3,702 died. The European Union predicts the crossings could exceed 500,000 in 2015, a spike the International Organization for Migration is warning could bring 10,000 deaths. | Photo by Sarah Caron

Adrift 2/6: A group of #migrants is pictured in a boat in the Mediterranean, between Libya and Sicily, in August 2014. Since 2000, around 22,000 Middle Easterners, Asians and Africans have drowned in the Mediterranean. In the past 18 months, the number of those trying to reach Europe—and dying along the way—has accelerated. As thousands die making the perilous journey from Africa to Europe, fleeing violence and searching for work, those that make it to Italy often end up stuck there. Unable to leave the reception centers that are meant to help them. The government has alleged that the mafia used intimidation and withholds money, food and clothing to make them too afraid to leave and dependent on them. | Photo by Sarah Caron

Adrift 1/6: The Mare Nostrum operation set up by the Italian Navy rescues migrants crossing the Mediterranean Sea in overloaded ramshackle boats. Organized crime is making a killing off migrants, especially if they survive the deadly journey to Europe. Not by smuggling people, but once refugees arrived, the #Mafia muscled in on the construction and management of the reception centers where the migrants were forced to live, often holding them there in order to continue collecting funds meant to aid the migrants. | Photo by Sarah Caron

Sure, everyone loves to hate @courtneylove, but our reporter @pmejia09 writes that the talented singer is turning the hate inside out. Read her take on why you're 100% wrong about #CourtneyLove at Newsweek.com | Art by @alvarotapiahidalgo
Gold rush: In the race to tap a melting #Arctic's riches, the U.S. lags far behind, with #Russia, #Canada and #China staking claims | On newsstands now!
The love vote: how corporate america propelled same-sex marriage. On newsstands now.

Fear not the Stranger 9/9: Every year #LaurensKids hosts a 1,500 mile walk from Key West to Tallahassee called "Walk in my Shoes" to raise awareness about children who are sexually abused. This year marks the 6th annual #WalkInMyShoes2015. "The walks are so hard," says Lauren Book, who founded Lauren's Kids. "I'm in pain," she adds, referring to shin splints and other injuries, "but that doesn't matter...there is a greater purpose for us, with what we're doing...Just because these terrible things happen, it doesn't mean we're not still incredibly strong, powerful people. We're not damaged goods."

Fear not the Stranger 8/9: Children often take to Book immediately, saying they trust her "because she is pretty," a stereotype she uses to help kids understand that not everyone they meet should be trusted so quickly and to challenge their assumptions of what a "bad guy" looks like.

Fear not the Stranger 7/9: Book tries to channel her experiences toward educating others how to recognize abuse. From time to time she visits the Florida Civil Commitment Center, a facility for post-incarceration treatment for convicted sexual offenders, to meet offenders and talk to them about how they got there. #Florida is among the harshest states in regards to punishment for sex offenders. Here, it is legal to lock up sex offenders after they've served their prison sentenced, as long as they've been deemed too dangerous to rejoin society | Read the story at Newsweek.com

Fear not the Stranger 6/9: Dozens of sex offenders have created a colony under #Miami's Julia Tuttle causeway bridge, living there due to zoning restrictions that leave them nowhere else to go. Miami-Dade county's Lauren Book Child Safety Ordinance law restricts registered sex offenders from living on average 2,500 feet from schools, day care centers and other places where children gather. | Read the story at Newsweek.com

Fear not the Stranger 5/9: In family photos everything appeared to be normal. Book, right, looked to be a happy child playing with her siblings while their nanny Waldina Flores looked on. But abuse was taking place regularly. Waldina was convicted of sexually abusing Book and subjecting her to years of rape, physical beatings and emotional abuse. | Read the story at Newsweek.com

#NewsweekArchive: @brandichastain rocked our cover in July 1999,  which was the last time the U.S. Women's Soccer team won the #WorldCup. Read our story about last night's U.S. victory against Japan, and watch #CarliLloyd's amazing goal from the halfway mark at Newsweek.com

Happy Independence Day! Throughout the day share with us your independent moments, be it #fireworks, grilling with family or sharing a favorite July 4th memory. At Newsweek we're most grateful today for the first amendment, which affords us the right to act as the fourth estate. What are you grateful for today? What makes #America great?

Fear not the Stranger 4/9: Book's father Ronald Book is a prominent Florida attorney and lobbyist. After the abuse of his daughter came to light he took it upon himself to tighten up enforcement and punishment for convinced sex offenders. He says he blames himself at time for not recognizing what was happening to Lauren.

Fear not the Stranger 3/9: Through her non-profit group Lauren's Kids, Book visits children at Glades Academy charter school in #Florida for a lesson about child sexual abuse and prevention. She says she tries to let children know that they need adults to talk to that they can trust, and that the danger is not always from a stranger with promises of candy or puppies | Read the story at Newsweek.com
Our own health reporter Jessica Firger sat down with @huffpostlive this morning to talk about #California's new vaccination law | Read the story at Newsweek.com

Fear not the Stranger 2/9: Lauren Book was sexually abused by her own nanny for five years. Now she heads up #LaurensKids, a non-profit that educates children and adults about child sexual abuse and prevention. One of the most important things Book tries to emphasize in her work is that sexual offenders are not your stereotypical strangers. The harsh reality is that the overwhelming majority of predators are in the victim’s family photo album or social circle. Ninety percent of children who are sexually abused know their abuser | Read the story at Newsweek.com

Fear not the Stranger 1/9: The old wisdom has always held that children must be warned of "stranger danger," but child sexual abuse victims more often than not know their predator. In the US, the issue is a bigger problem than many people realize. One in three girls and one in five boys are sexually abused by the time they turn 18, and around 90 percent of individuals with development disabilities will be sexually abused at some point | Read the story at Newsweek.com

The predator next door: Child abuse is a plague we can't stop because we are looking for predators in all the wrong places. Nearly all children who are sexually abused know their abusers | On newsstands now!

Love is Love 4/4: Doug Mest, left, and Mark Pelekakis, second left, of Los Angeles, kiss outside the Stonewall Inn in New York City after the U.S. Supreme court ruling. The Stonewall Inn was the location of riots where gay people fought with police during a bar raid in June 28, 1969. The riots are largely credited with sparking the modern gay rights movement. | Check out live coverage at Newsweek.com

Love is Love 3/4: Under the ruling same-sex couples have a constitutional right to marry nationwide, the U.S. Supreme Court said in a historic ruling that caps the biggest civil rights transformation in a half-century. | Check out live coverage at Newsweek.com

Love is Love 2/4: Lupe Garcia, left, hugs her partner Cindy Stocking, right,  at the Travis County building after hearing the Supreme Court ruling that grants same-sex couples the right to marry nationwide, Friday, June 26, 2015, in Austin, Texas. | Check out live coverage at Newsweek.com

Love is Love 1/4: Washington DC - Same-sex marriage supporters take a selfie in front of the Supreme Court as they wait for the court to legalize same-sex marriages nationwide on Friday, June 26, 2015. In a 5-4 decision, the US Supreme Court legalized gay marriage nationwide, citing the constitutions equal protection clause as their rational. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote the majority opinion: “No union is more profound than marriage, for it embodies the highest ideals of love, fidelity, devotion, sacrifice, and family,” he wrote. “In forming a marital union, two people become something greater than once they were.” | Check out live coverage at Newsweek.com

Baked Alaska 16/16: The Togiak National Wildlife Refuge, viewed from the air just East of Togiak, shows evidence of the winter's limited snowfall. April 21, 2015. The Yupik people of Togiak are watching their world melt away from under their feet. Photo by @joshuacorbettphotography #AssignmentNewsweek
When drug addicts work in hospitals, no one is safe. When hospitals cover up crimes, people die. One junkie's harrowing journey across America, in this week's Newsweek.

Baked Alaska 15/16: Travis Logusak and Brekin Gosuk walk into the Togiak Bay shore east of town after an unsuccessful duck hunt on April 23, 2015. Even hunting for ducks has proven difficult as the birds change their migration paths or avoid ares that no longer have reliable food source for them. Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by@joshuacorbettphotography#AssignmentNewsweek

Baked Alaska 14/16: The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service allots the entire village of Togiak a “community harvest” of two walruses, with the meat, blubber and skin shared and bartered among households, sometimes with neighboring villages. What used to be a cultural treat has become a bigger part of the their diet. The guttural Yupik language spoken by many in Togiak, and exclusively by some of the oldest tribal elders, has no word for “subsistence.” Hunting, fishing and foraging are not quaint traditions; they are the anchors of Yupik life and culture—of yuuyaraq, which roughly means “the way of being a human.” Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by@joshuacorbettphotography#AssignmentNewsweek

Baked Alaska 13/16: Some three-quarters of those over 16 in the village are not formally employed, and average per capita income is just $11,739, so subsistence skills are essential to survival. Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by@joshuacorbettphotography#AssignmentNewsweek

Baked Alaska 12/16: “There’s so much not normal stuff going on,” says Clara Ann Martin, 54, who is also on the Traditional Council of Togiak, during a birthday party for a friend’s young daughter. Ten years ago, Martin says, “elders said, ‘No, no, no, it’s not happening.’ But now they see the lack of snow, the tree growth, the lesions on caribou.... Climate change is happening in our face.” Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by @joshuacorbettphotography #AssignmentNewsweek

Baked Alaska 11/16: An unusually warm winter brings changes in summer and fall too. In recent years, the sockeye salmon runs, a splendid profusion of scarlet-red fish with newly bottle-green heads muscling up the Togiak River and eight other rivers feeding into the bay, have come unexpectedly early and petered out quickly. Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by @joshuacorbettphotography #AssignmentNewsweek

Baked Alaska 10/16: An airport security agent checks a box for contraband. While two small general stores sell basics from cereal to jelly, the cost of flying them in makes prices astronomical (a 1.5-liter bottle of Wesson cooking oil retails for $25; a 25-pound bag of flour costs over $53). The high prices have created an underground trade where items like diapers, oil and alcohol are sneaked into the town. Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by @joshuacorbettphotography #AssignmentNewsweek
An asteroid took out the dinosaurs, but humans have the ability to track them and the technology to stop them. But who will foot the bill? On newsstands now.

Baked Alaska 9/16: Peter Lockuk Jr. and Jim Logusak look over the trades they'd made with a shipping crew. Using a small raft to travel from boat to boat in Togiak Bay is a dangerous task, rough waters or hostile crews aside, there is always the chance that valuable fuel could be wasted roaming the seas and not heating their homes. Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by @joshuacorbettphotography #AssignmentNewsweek

Baked Alaska 8/16: Crew members on a herring processing ship look over Lockuk's wares for trade. Without snow on the ground to go hunting or an abundance of fish in the sea, some people in Togiak have turned to trading clothing, homemade art or any other valuable they have. Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by @joshuacorbettphotography #AssignmentNewsweek

Baked Alaska 7/16: Peter Lockuk Jr. looks out over Togiak Bay from a shipping freight he'd boarded in an effort to trade with the crew for money or food. Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by@joshuacorbettphotography#AssignmentNewsweek

Baked Alaska 6/16: Remnants of broken down boats and snowmobiles scavenged for parts lie in a heap. Without snow, the snowmobiles that allow to hunting and getting across dangerous terrain are useless. Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by @joshuacorbettphotography #AssignmentNewsweek

Baked Alaska 5/16: Young people in Togiak live much the same way as their parents did before them, passing the time my playing outside and helping adults with hunting, cooking and cleaning when called on. Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by @joshuacorbettphotography #AssignmentNewsweek

Baked Alaska 4/16: Frank Logusak sits on his son's snowmobile behind his home in Togiak Alaska on April 22, 2015. The past winter's limited snowfall made accessing hunting grounds more difficult for hunters in the community. Read the story at Newsweek.com | Photo by @joshuacorbettphotography #AssignmentNewsweek

A page from Page 5/5: A Korean marine takes a moment to himself after a firefight, near Quang Nghai, in 1966. Page says #Vietnam is a place where he lost "mentors and mates - missing forever, their legacy now in those pages. Images that will endure history. The strongest anti-war statement – for all good war pictures have that effect." Page now lives peacefully in Brisbane, Australia. | Photo by Tim Page

A page from Page 4/5: Soldiers arrive at at the site of ambush attack on the 173rd in the #IronTriangle in 1965. It was pictures like these, far removed from the romanticism of World War II, that brought the battlefield to the public eye and turned Americans against the #VietnamWar | Photo by Tim Page

A page from Page 3/5: During the Mini-Tet at the Y-Bridge, photojournalist Tim Page was huddled with fellow photojournalist Philip Jones Griffith, Larry Burrows and Shimamoto San around the back of a fire brigade truck. In the truck bed he found the remains of a gunned-down body and the cries of her younger brother above her. "And there’s not one selfie of any of us." Page said. | Photo by Tim Page. #VietnamWar

A page from Page 2/5: Veteran war reporter Sean Flynn, left, with photojournalist Tim Page near the hovercraft base east of Perfume River. The two became close friends in Vietnam, as Flynn showed Page the ropes of war reporting. Flynn was known as a journalist who pushed himself for the best images- a trait which may have cost him his life. On April 6, 1970 he departed down a highway toward Saigon and was never seen again. It is suspected he was captured by the Viet Cong, but no remains were ever found. Page eventually wrote about his missing friend and devoted his book to the memory of 135 photojournalist who died in #Vietnam. | Photo by Mike Herr

A page from Page 1/5: Korean troops encounter terrified villagers sheltering from their helicopter assault in Bong Son, Vietnam, in June 1966. On the 40th anniversary of the #FallofSaigon, photojournalist Tim Page spoke to us about his time covering the war as a 20-year-old in war-torn Vietnam. | Photo by Tim Page

Chained 2/3: At home with her son in New York in 2013, this former agunah became disillusioned with Judaism after waiting years for a "get" and and no longer subscribes to an Orthodox lifestyle. Photo by Aviva Klein

Chained 1/3: In Orthodox Judaism, a husband must give a "get" to his wife for a divorce to be official. Most do, but the ones who refuse wield enormous power over their wives. Even with a civil divorce decree in hand, a woman is not divorced in the Orthodox Jewish world until her husband allows it. Until then, she is an agunah, a “chained” woman. If she decides to remarry without the "get," she would be considered an adulteress, and her children shunned. Here a former Agunah who is now happily remarried stands in her home in Connecticut, 2013. Photo by Aviva Klein

Health workers carry the body of an #Ebola victim in Kenema, Sierra Leone, June 25, 2014. The Ebola outbreak has killed 467 people in Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone since February, making it the largest and deadliest ever, according to the World Health Organization (WHO). West African states lack the resources to battle the world's worst outbreak of Ebola and deep cultural suspicions about the disease remain a big obstacle to halting its spread, ministers said on Wednesday.

Medical staff take a blood sample from a suspected #Ebola patient at the government hospital in Kenema, Sierra Leone, July 10, 2014. Ebola has killed 632 people across Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone since an outbreak began in February, putting strain on a string of weak health systems facing one of the world's deadliest diseases despite waves of international help.
#Ebola outbreaks since 1976.

Health workers, wearing head-to-toe protective gear, prepare for work, outside an isolation unit in Foya District, Lofa County, #Liberia in this July 2014 UNICEF handout photo. As of July 27, 2014, a total of 1,323 cases, including 729 deaths, had been attributed to #Ebola virus disease (EVD) in the four West African countries of Guinea, Liberia, Nigeria and Sierra Leone. Liberia has borne 329 of these cases, including 156 deaths.

Volunteers lower a corpse, which is prepared with safe burial practices to ensure it does not pose a health risk to others and stop the chain of person-to-person transmission of #Ebola, into a grave in Kailahun, August 2, 2014. Hundreds of troops were deployed in #SierraLeone and #Liberia on Monday to quarantine communities hit by the deadly Ebola virus, as the death toll from the worst-ever outbreak reached 887 and three new cases were reported in #Nigeria.

45 years ago, three brave astronauts launched into space with the goal of becoming the first to walk on the moon. The now-legendary #Apollo11 crew of Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin and Michael Collins left the planet on July 16, 1969, setting off from Florida's Kennedy Space Center and arriving on the Moon four days later. On July 20, "with one small step," Neil Armstrong made history, becoming the first person to set foot on the moon. The next day, his smiling face was on the cover of Newsweek. Like most Americans, Newsweek's editors were fascinated by this moment in space history. Newsweek reported on the space age dozens of times (45 cover stories) from October 1957, when Sputnik 1 went into orbit, through the Apollo landing on the moon in July 1969, including six cover stories devoted specifically to Apollo missions in that year
An Israeli rocket is fired into the northern #Gaza Strip, July 17 2014. 📷 Amir Cohen/Reuters.

Newsweek Rewind: If it turns out that the Malaysia Airlines 777 that crashed in Ukraine was indeed shot down, it won’t be the first time a commercial airliner was downed by military action. The most infamous instance occurred in 1983: Korean Air Lines Flight 007, a jumbo jet carrying 269 people, was gunned down by a Sukhoi Su-15 fighter jet after straying into Soviet airspace. The cost to the United States of the Iraq War has been immense: Between 2003 and the end of 2012, 4,486 American servicemen and women were killed. Another 33,000 were wounded. (Before that, in 1991, 382 American military personnel were killed in the first Iraq War, which drove Saddam’s army out of Kuwait, the neighboring oil-rich country to Iraq’s south.) The toll on Iraqis has been far greater. According to the Iraq Body Count project, an independent research group that tries to monitor casualties, up to 114,731 Iraqis have been killed to date in a war that, for them, continues.

Newsweek reporters covered the #Tiananmen Square massacre extensively with two cover stories, each followed by additional reports of the tragedy, under the banner "Upheaval in China." From "Beijing Bloodbath": "With plumes of tear gas and arcs of tracer bullets, the long-awaited crackdown on protesters in Tiananmen Square got underway Saturday night. Armored personnel carriers breached human barricades, and Chinese soldiers opened fire on the crowds. As day broke on Sunday, hundreds of protesters lay dead; countless more were injured. The suppression may have shown the resolve of a leadership crippled for weeks by a power struggle and humiliated by inability to control its own capital city. But in the process Beijing jeopardized a decade of reforms and squandered a global fund of good will."
Burned and destroyed armored personnel carriers, Fuxing Road, Beijing, China June 1989. 📷 Alon Reininger/Contact Press Images.
The #Tiananmen protest swelled to hundreds of thousands. Students gathered around a a 10-metre replica of the Statue of Liberty (C), called the Goddess of Democracy. 📷 Catherine Henriette/AFP/Getty

In mid-April, 1989, students gathered in China's historic Tiananmen square in a hunger protest for democracy. The protests would grow, gather support from their countryman, and shake the Communist country to its core. And they would end in bloodshed, as the Chinese army used live ammunition and tanks to clear the square. Photo: Tanks deploy in eastern Beijing, China, June 5, 1989. 📷 Liu Heung Shing/AP.

Author and poet Maya Angelou has died at age 86 in North Carolina. Angelou provided eloquent commentary on race, gender and living life to its fullest in poems and memoirs such as "I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings," which brought her wide acclaim. She wrote more than 30 books and was a Grammy winner for three spoken-word albums. She had a home in Winston-Salem, North Carolina, where she was a professor of American studies at Wake Forest University. She was honored at the National Book Awards ceremony last year for her service to the literary community. Photo: Maya Angelou receives a Medal of Freedom from U.S. President Barack Obama. 📷 Larry Downing/Reuters.

n her first public appearance since she was fired by The New York Times, Jill Abramson delivered the commencement address to Wake Forest University's class of 2014 Monday on the subject of resilience. “Very early last Thursday my sister called. She said, ‘I know dad would be as proud of you today as the day you became executive editor of The New York Times,’” Abramson recalled in her speech. “I’d been fired the previous day, so I knew what she was trying to say: It meant more to our father to see us deal with a setback and try to bounce back than to watch how we handled our successes. ‘Show what you are made of,’ he would say.” 📷 Jason Miczek/Reuters.

Next month, John Lennon fans have a rare chance to buy his whimsical sketches, cartoons and poems at Sotheby's. The collection belongs to Tom Maschler, the legendary publisher and editor who, in 1964, persuaded Lennon to compile some of his drawings and writing for a book, "In His Own Write," published by Maschler, with a follow-up, "A Spaniard In The Works," a year later. 📷 Paul Hackett/Reuters.

A Muslim couple prays over the grave of a relative at the #Srebrenica Genocide Memorial, officially known as the Srebrenica-Potočari Memorial and Cemetery for the Victims of the 1995 Genocide. The victims buried at Srebrenica were mostly male and Bosnian Muslims. Every year hundreds of newly identified victims found in mass graves are buried here. 📷 @ErinTrieb.

A young Bosnian woman rides a bus in #Sarajevo. Cultural identity in #Bosnia varies among its youth. Many young women embrace Western influence and styles, while others adhere to more conservative traditions, such as wearing the headscarf. 📷 @ErinTrieb

A man stands on a street undergoing construction outside a hair salon in Mostar, Bosnia and Herzegovina. After Bosnia and Herzegovina declared independence from Yugoslavia, Mostar was subjected to an 18-month siege. Much of the city is still in ruins and under construction. Although Western countries have pumped millions of international aid dollars in to the region over the past 20 years, Bosnia currently lacks the industry required to produce significant economic growth. Along with a struggling economy, tensions remain high between Bosnia's three people groups: Bosnians, Croatians and Serbians. 📷 @ErinTrieb.

Almost 20 years after the war in Bosnia and Herzegovina (1992–1995), site of Europe’s worst genocide since World War II, the echoes of the conflict still haunt the country’s land. Photo: Overlooking the valley of Romanija, the ground begins to thaw after winter’s first frost. 📷 @ErinTrieb.

An estimated 800,000 people were killed in 100 days during the genocide. 📷 Noor Khamis/Reuters.

For this week's print magazine, we spent time with Angelina Jolie to learn about her efforts to find  justice for the survivors of Bosnia's mass rapes. Between 1992 and 1995, an estimated 20,000 to 50,000 men, women, and boys were raped in Bosnia. Jolie has returned to Bosnia with British Foreign Secretary William Hague to promote their partnership directed at preventing sexual violence in conflict. Rape during wartime is often treated as a lesser war crime, and their initiative is an attempt to galvanize political will to uphold international standards of justice. 📷 Amel Emric/AP.
Why are so many farmers killing themselves? We investigate in this week's cover story by Max Kutner.  On news stands & online at Newsweek.com.

Kurt Cobain passed away twenty years ago today. His too-early passing was watershed moment for a generation and for fans of the grunge trend he spawned. Cobain was featured on the cover of Newsweek's April 18, 1994, issue as part of a larger story about the root causes of suicide. He was presented alongside other historical celebrity victims of suicide. You can view our 1994 eulogy in "Newsweek Rewind: Remembering Kurt Cobain" on Newsweek.com.

On the 46th anniversary of the assassination of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., his family is at war over his legacy.

Squabbles among the adult children of a famous patriarch are common, but the rancorous disputes of the King siblings—most of them over lucrative licensing deals for their father’s words and image—are rending family ties and friendships forged during some of the most harrowing battles of the civil rights movement. We explore this in this week's #Newsweek cover story.

Photo: After Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. is freed from prison under a $2000 appeal bond, he is greeted by his wife Coretta and children, Marty and Yoki, at the airport in Chamblee, Georgia, Oct 27, 1960. Bettmann/Corbis.

With the 20th anniversary of Kurt Cobain's death approaching on April 5, we'd like to celebrate the musician's vast contributions to music and popular culture by reprinting our 1994 tribute.

Cobain was featured on the cover of Newsweek's April 18, 1994, issue as part of a larger story about the root causes of suicide. From "The Mystery of Suicide," by David Gelman: "The road to self-destruction starts with depression and ends in the grave. But who chooses to die and why? Is it stress? Brain chemistry? A despair rotting the soul? The answers are as varied as the weapons." Gelman spoke to Seattle locals about Cobain's too-early passing. College student Chris Dorr, 23, found it almost clichéd: "It makes you wonder if our icons are genetically programmed to self-destruct in their late 20s." Visit Newsweek.com to read our 1994 eulogy, a feature that ran alongside Gelman's story.

Shadowed by Secret Servicemen President Barack Obama arrives at Schiphol Airport to attend the Nuclear Security Summit in the Hague earlier this week. The crisis over the Crimean peninsula has cast a shadow of its own over Obama's agenda. He planned to discuss further sanctions against Russia with European leaders; but Europe's dependence on Russian oil and other economic considerations will complicate the conversation. And while international events have demanded the president's attention lately, a key part of his domestic agenda is in the news as March 31 approaches--that's the deadline by which uninsured Americans have to sign up for health care coverage. 📷 Peter Dejong/AP.

The Fall/Winter adl + CENGİZ show during Istanbul Fashion Week. Twice yearly, Istanbul’s Fashion Week draws a varied crowd—from the religiously conservative to social liberals. Recent trends highlighted versatility, allowing the wearer to tailor designer outfits to conservative tastes. Dresses can be worn over pants, and longer coats make curves less pronounced. Scarves are culled from top designers such as Louis Vuitton and Hermés. Filling the need for high-end Islamic fashion is Turkish fashion magazine Ala, which the press calls the “Vogue of the veiled.” The magazine’s spreads feature bright colors and modern cuts while still maintaining modesty and Islamic values. 📷 Monique Jaques/@moniquejaques.

A widow throws flowers into the air during the Holi celebrations organised by non-governmental organization Sulabh International at a widows' ashram in Vrindavan in the northern Indian state of Uttar Pradesh March 14, 2014. Traditionally in Hindu culture, widows are expected to renounce earthly pleasure so they do not celebrate Holi. But women at the shelter for widows, who have been abandoned by their families, celebrated the festival by throwing flowers and coloured powder. Holi, also known as the Festival of Colors, heralds the beginning of spring and is celebrated all over India. 📷 Ahmad Masood/Reuters.

#TBT #NewsweekRewind On March 12, 1989, British computer scientist Sir Tim Berners-Lee proposed an “information management” system that would become known as the Web. We celebrate the twenty-fifth anniversary of his world-changing invention on the first edition of our new weekly feature, Newsweek Rewind. We dug through our archive and pulled our first article about the Web, from our October 31, 1994 issue. Go to Newsweek.com for the full text of the piece, “Oh, what a Tangled Web,” by Barbara Kantrowitz with Adam Rogers and Jennifer Tanaka.

Photo essay: Railway Renegades 📷 Valerio Polici. Becoming an adult is a complex and sometimes painful process. Terrified by this transition, some people stay in a halfway stage before youth’s tranquility and carelessness vanish forever. I decided to tell the story of this suspended state through several communities of young graffiti writers that I followed for two years in Europe and Argentina, who have found the perfect tool to evade adulthood. Graffiti lets them linger in a limbo of myths, legends and heroic deeds. They are drawn to the appeal of being an outlaw, the obstacles, and the theatricality of their targets. This is the story of their escape and to a certain extent also about mine.

Photo: Passing through a hole in the fence to reach the subway depot in Rome.

#graffiti #photography #photojournalism #rome #naples #buenosaires #lisbon
